During the war, military training and anti-German propaganda strove to make men better soldiers both by encouraging homoeroticism among the troops and, paradoxically, by projecting homophobia onto the enemy. As Eric Leed cautions, understanding the war experience requires not merely balancing "its undeniably positive and negative features," but recognizing "how both the positive and negative sides of the war are emanations of the same phenomenon." 10 Accordingly, Joanna Bourke points out that while the development of intimate male friendships made the war "less unbearable and more human . . . male bonding was not [exclusively] an inevitable, organic sentiment of the war: it was in the interests of military authorities to foster in servicemen a sense of group solidarity." 11 Indeed, the military discouraged male bonding when it interfered with the war effort. Following the legendary Christmas Day truce of 1914, during which men from both sides of the conflict created a temporary domestic space by singing carols, sharing food, and exchanging souvenirs, "stringent regulations were immediately issued to prevent it from happening again, and the whole system of military justice was brought into play." 12 The proper lesson to learn from Christmas was not universal brotherhood, the military urged, but "redemption through suffering," which would "make men hard" (ibid.).

Even as soldiers were encouraged to make themselves hard, they simultaneously learned to mark the enemy as feminine and sexually deviant. Recent feminist scholarship perceives war as a "gendering activity that ritually marks the gender" of all its participants, whether combatant or civilian. 13 During World War I, the British gender system extended the binary opposition of masculine/feminine to battlefront/homefront and soldier/enemy as part of an overall pattern of control. The reality of trench warfare--where men cowered helplessly below the earth at the mercy of shells exploding above them--provoked a crisis of masculinity evident not just in "a generalized sexual anxiety" but also, as Sandra Gilbert observes, in "a sexual anger directed specifically against" the feminine. 14 Demonization of the enemy operated as a vital mechanism for the war's continuance: killing without remorse and maintaining aggression in an essentially defensive war required combatants to un-recognize their German opponent, to identify him as not-man and bond together as men in pursuit of his destruction. Thus, as Claire Tylee concludes, by valorizing heroic sacrifice and tragic martyrdom, the dominant myths of World War I gloss over the army's manipulation of masculine ideals in order to drive men to their maximum killing potential (GW, 254-5). "The German Prisoner" reminds us why men are sent to war--to kill and maim each other--demonstrating how ethnic and class divisions, homophobia, and misogyny help make this carnage possible.

Empire, Class, and "The German Prisoner"

Foregrounding the hostility and alienation of British imperial society, James Hanley's proletarian Irish perspective challenges the myth of a collective loss of innocence that suffuses officers' memoirs and continues to dominate cultural memory. Many soldiers experienced and remembered World War I as being profoundly influenced by their ethnicity and class status. Britain in 1914 was a nation troubled by the appalling conditions of urban slums, suffragist challenges to patriarchy, threats of strikes at home, and imminent civil war in Ireland. As Tylee points out, the "prelapsarian fantasy" of a prewar, unified nation reflecting British nostalgia for an idealized childhood and "lost imperial splendor" is specific to the upper-class English male (GW, 245). In Sassoon's Memoirs of a Fox Hunting Man, Rebecca West finds a "heartrending portrait of a class that was allowed to play at being children until the war came, and then was delivered, bound hand and foot, to the forces of hell." 15 Hanley's life and fiction, however, provide a powerful corrective to the notion that prewar Britain nurtured innocence and idealism in all its youth. His 1931 novel, Boy--in which a cabin boy is repeatedly molested by older men, infected with syphilis in an Alexandrian brothel, and then tossed overboard like garbage--describes a hellish alternative to Sassoon's extended adolescence.

Born in Dublin , Hanley spent most of his childhood in an immigrant community in Liverpool before going to sea at the age of thirteen to serve as a ship's boy. Whatever his experiences were at sea, combat apparently offered a more attractive alternative. Deserting ship in New Brunswick, he lied about his age and signed up with the Canadian army, eventually serving with shock troops in France. 16 After being discharged with injuries sustained in a gas attack, Hanley returned to Liverpool, where he struggled for years against poverty, working, among other menial jobs, as a docker and racetrack cashier. 17 Hanley thus describes the war from the perspective of a working-class soldier who experiences the dehumanization of the trenches as an intensification of, rather than a radical departure from, his position in society. 18

"The German Prisoner" opens as a battalion of men from Dublin, Cork, Donegal, and England's industrial slums hunker down for a night in a bombed-out house that resembles a stable. Treated like animals, the men behave and smell accordingly. They attack their food with "savagery" and fill the rooms with their sweat and "their almost pesty breath" ("GP," 7). Within this bestiary, two huddle apart. Hanley makes clear the closeted nature of their relationship when he writes, "In the darkest corner of one of the rooms on the ground floor lay two men . . . facing each other" in a "recumbent position" (ibid.). The taller and heavier of the men, Peter O'Garra, is Irish, impoverished, and inverted--on the ladder of the British Empire you can't descend much lower than this. O'Garra's companion, Elston, is also working-class. Born in the slums of Manchester, and described by O'Garra as the "suck-holing type," he occupies a position only fractionally better. Parodying the officers' familiar sentimentality, Elston misses the "smoke and fog and grease" of his home and feels nostalgic for his "little corner of the world," filthy and rotten though it may be. O'Garra, by contrast, harbors no regrets for the "drab life of Tara Street," with "its lousiness, its human animals herded together, its stinkin' mattresses" ("GP," 9). During World War I, Dublin boasted the worst slums in Europe, with one-third of its population crammed into single rooms that housed up to twenty people who slept as many as eight in a bed. Such conditions bred a tuberculosis rate twice as high as London's. It is therefore not surprising that Dublin,which also manifested the highest death rate and greatest percentage of people living in poverty of any city in the United Kingdom, inspired little nostalgia in those who left. 19 Further, Dubliners who migrated to English cities such as Liverpool often found themselves isolated in pockets of Irish abjection, reliving the circumstances they had fled.

Britain's justification of imperialism as a civilizing mission necessitated by the colonial subject's primitivism was fine-tuned in Ireland; and for the Irish who came to work in England, class antagonisms fused with ethnic stereotyping. 20 The discourse of British racial superiority required the Irish male to be less than a man, whether in Matthew Arnold's well-intentioned celebration of the feminine qualities of the Celt or in the vicious satires of Punch. One such satire, entitled "The Missing Link," detailed how explorers venturing into "the lowest districts of London and Liverpool" would encounter "the lowest species of Irish Yahoo . . . a climbing animal . . . ascending a ladder laden with a hod of bricks," ready to attack "civilised beings that have provoked its fury." 21 During the war, both the arrival of a German ship on the Irish coast and the Easter Rising confirmed fears of Irish treachery and violence. And the identification of the Irish enemy with sexual deviance was simultaneously reinforced by the execution of Roger Casement for treason following the revelation of scandalous diaries containing evidence of homosexual encounters throughout the colonies. According to Enda Duffy, Casement's "rebellious patriotic martyrdom" was thereby "transformed by insinuation into a discourse of forbidden sexuality," and his "choice of political action" reduced to "the merely predictable expression of an inner secret." 22

Given the wartime association of the Irish with treason, sexual deviance, and subhumanity, it is easy to see why Hanley rejected the "known literary forms" that Fussell insists war writers could not avoid (GWM, 174). Rather, Hanley's war memoir bypasses the mythic chivalry of English national literature for the idiom of jingoistic, working-class humor he had internalized from British satires of the Irish people's attempts to overcome biology. There is much of the "stage Irishman" about O'Garra (whose very name has echoes of "begorra," an expression prominent in Irish theater), and indeed, at times, Hanley appears to be writing stage directions rather than description. 23 O'Garra spits on the floor, "following up the action by drawing the flat of his hand across his mouth" ("GP," 8). As the troops prepare to move out, O'Garra and Elston execute a pratfall straight from the music hall:

Suddenly O'Garra slipped into a hole.
"Jesus Christ! Already," growled Elston.
He dragged O'Garra out, following up the action by falling in himself. ["GP,"11]

Such exaggerated actions emphasize the absurdity of the humiliating and degrading role they must perform in order to survive. There is no touch of elegy, no sense of sacrifice in Hanley's description of battle, which he records with darkly physical humor. A sergeant named Grundy announces his intention to "post certain men," provoking "all and sundry" to break into "loud cursing and obscene oaths" ("GP," 17). Brains belonging to a soldier named Gorman end up splattered on O'Garra's forehead. And in another scene Elston screams "like a stuck pig" on finding himself "drenched in blood":

"Oh funkin' hell. I'm killed. I'm dead. O'Garra. O'Garra. O'Garra."
"Shut up," growled the Irishman. "Can't you see that bugger behind you. You got a belt in the back with his head. See. He hasn't any now. That whizz-bang took his head and his arse off him at the same time. . . ." ["GP," 19]

The voices Hanley records with such accuracy in "The German Prisoner" are those from "the end of the line," the lowest level of combat troops, lacking either agency or access to information about their fate.

Joanna Bourke notes that "the ideology of male comradeship in war was never intended to subvert military rank and its association with socioeconomic class"; at the height of the battle the men do their job, which is not to think, but to move forward, to follow orders (DM, 145). They form a corporate body, a "huge eyeless monster that forge[s] its way ahead towards some inevitable destiny. Nothing more" ("GP," 12). At times, however, the mass disintegrates into its constituent parts. One memorable scene from "The German Prisoner" deflates the classic war texts' romanticization of the officer's relationship to his men. Knowing that a guide waits for them a thousand yards ahead, an officer worries about his men for strategic reasons alone: some might die, yes, but to leave them out in the open would "disclose (more importantly) the movements of troops . . . to the Germans" and ruin the element of surprise ("GP," 14). "Far back, at the very tail end of this file of men," Elston and O'Garra have been worrying about the officer's competence, complaining that "that bugger in front" can't re out what to do. As the cover of darkness lifts, the men begin to panic--"what had merely been a germ, became a disease, an epidemic. The torment was no longer private, but general. . . . When something went wrong, the more sensitive spirits became agitated. One saw it in their eyes" ("GP," 15). After a bombardment kills seven men, the troops issue their own orders: "RUN FOR IT" ("GP," 16).

As John Keegan shows, the average soldier answers to a different imperative than the officer: "the concepts 'win' and 'lose' through which a commander . . . approach[es] a battle are by no means the same as those through which his men will view their own involvement in it." 24 Studies of human behavior in combat reveal that men identify themselves in terms of a "very tiny" group, "perhaps no more than six or seven men." Group members begin to t and continue to t for two reasons: "personal survival, which individuals will recognize to be bound up with group survival" and the "fear of incurring by cowardly conduct the group's contempt." 25 Further, noting the "immense burden" masculine comradeship placed on men "to express martial values," Bourke observes that in World War I, "the fear of being thought to be a coward was intense" (DM, 151-2). Tylee adds that to feel fear provoked deep shame in a man, causing him to "despise himself as he might a member of an 'inferior' race or a girl" (GW, 125). Masculinity taught men to repress fear of the other within, thereby directing shame and self-loathing into aggression against a designated object outside themselves.

Of the two men, O'Garra seems to be the better soldier, having learned the masculine ability to maintain control over himself and other men. He brags about surviving the first gas attack, and he repeatedly pulls Elston out of danger as the other man whimpers for his mother. 26 Years of abuse on a filthy street in the most despised corner of the British Empire have steeled O'Garra against attacks. The litany of insults with which his Dublin neighbors revile him constitutes the same equation between homosexuality and treason found in British propaganda:

a lousy bugger--a rake--a closet--a quiet fellow--a tub of guts--a pimp--a shit-house--a toad--a sucker--a blasted sod--a Holy Roller--a Tara lemon--a Judas--a jumped-up liar--a book-worm--a traitor to Ireland--a pervert--an Irish jew--an Irish Christ--a clod. ["GP," 8]

Despite their rejection of him as "a traitor to Ireland," O'Garra's countrymen uphold British associations of Ireland with deviance, using "Irish" and "Tara" as intensifiers of their own scorn. Demonized as a pervert, an animal, and a traitor to race and religion, O'Garra seeks in aggression a more acceptable alternative to this identity. We learn that he "went for a soldier" to keep from giving in to "blood" that was "heavy with surrender" ("GP," 9). War is just "blood bitterness," he tells Elston, "and bitter blood is good blood" (ibid.). This struggle has taken its toll, however. His eyes, which Hanley compares to "the dried up beds of African lakes," reveal the double repression of his identity as racialized colonial subject and as sexual other.

O'Garra has so internalized society's prejudices that he can't open his mouth without a disparaging remark about "buggers" and "sods." Self-hatred translates his attraction to Elston as hate at first sight: "When first he had set eyes on Elston, he had despised him, there was something in this man utterly repugnant to him" ("GP," 10). From his first encounter with this "human rat," this Englishman of the "suck-holing type," O'Garra obsesses about how despicable he finds the other man, penning verses that testify to Elston's uniqueness as an object of scorn.

Annihilating Desire

A cultural complex of homophobia, misogyny, racial and class discrimination, and repressed sexual desire erupt into violence and brutality in the relationship between O'Garra and Elston, provoking their rape and murder of a German prisoner. The anxiety shared by cultural historians over pronounced homoeroticism in literary representations of the war is exemplified by Fussell's coining of the phrase "chaste homosexuality" to bolster his claim that virtually none of these crushes were ever consummated. In fact, between 1914 and 1919, "twenty-two officers and 270 other ranks were court-martialed for 'indecency' with another man." 27 Reminding us that "the war provided opportunities for erotic relationships among men which were not necessarily available in peacetime," Trudi Tate suggests we examine why the idea of homosexuality has been so obdurately resisted. 28 Certainly the identification during and after the war of homosexuality as a German practice provided an added incentive for men to remain silent about their own behavior: newspapers condemned infection by "German homosexuality" as threatening "the patriotism, stamina, intellect and morale" of the troops. 29

In "The German Prisoner," however, the fog of war is also the fog of desire, even if O'Garra and Elston consistently misname and misrecognize their passion. The lid is clamped down so tightly that neither can envision the realization of his desire without an eruption of violence. As the troops "go over the top" into no-man's-land,

every sound and every movement seemed to strike a responsive chord in the Irishman's nature. He hung on desperately to the Manchester man. . . . He could not understand this sudden desire for Elston's company. But the desire overwhelmed him. ["GP," 19]

Something about battle turns O'Garra on. Seeing a once-foolish officer's "headless body" stirs "something deep down in the bosom of his soul" ("GP," 28). After they lose contact with their battalion, the fog deepens and Elston regards O'Garra with "a sudden gust of fear and passion," wondering "did this man really mean to murder him" ("GP," 22).

When O'Garra looks "across at the huddled form of the Manchester man," he heaves a sigh, acknowledging, but still unable to articulate, his yearning: "Now the whole of his past shot across the surface of that mind" (ibid.). Remembering "those lonely nights, those fruitless endeavors" spent searching for a woman, O'Garra concludes, "surely they took on a richer texture now. . . . [A]chieved a certain significance" ("GP," 22-3). He defers his sexual confusion with a deep meditation on what will happen after the war. Unable to re out why he "had come into all this muck and mud and madness," he gropes instead for a suitable target for the grudge he believes "everyone in the war must bear," wondering "would they all demand retribution? Would they all wreak a terrible vengeance?" ("GP," 23).

Waking from this reverie, O'Garra realizes that his watch has stopped, imparting to the scene the strange, surrealistic quality of a dream sequence. Suddenly, out of the mist emerges a handsome German soldier boy embodying the homoerotic ideal described by classic war memoirs. 30 Hanley invokes him lyrically, as "tall, with a form as graceful as a young sapling," with hair "as fair as ripe corn, . . . blue eyes, and finely molded features" ("GP," 24). In the ensuing brutal scene, "The German Soldier" enacts the men's projection of unsafe desire on an enemy who must consequently be destroyed. 31 Calling out repeatedly, "Camerade. Camerade," the German boy pleads for recognition of their common humanity. Initially Elston recognizes this appeal, responding that they too are lost and asking, "Is it foggy where you came from? . . . [W]e'll never get out of this hole, only by stirring ourselves together and making a bolt for it" ("GP," 25). O'Garra, however, chokes off the possibility of fellowship with a torrent of homophobic slurs, warning Elston, "perhaps this sod is leading us into a trap. Why not finish the bugger off, anyhow?" In the fog of war, innocence provokes violence, and murder reveals its erotic potential. O'Garra and Elston savagely kick the screaming prisoner's face into a bloody pulp. The remorse and horror they feel afterwards ends quickly. Reminiscing about an earlier incident, in which O'Garra pulled another soldier off an old woman during what appears to have been a serial rape, the two excitedly urinate over the prisoner. And their subsequent expressions of renewed vigor are clearly postcoital:

"Hell!" exclaimed O'Garra. "After that I feel relieved. Refreshed. Don't feel tired. Don't feel anything particularly. How do you feel?" he asked.
"The same," replied Elston. "But I wish to Christ this soddin' fog would lift." ["GP," 30]

The world of "The German Prisoner" is liquid with water, blood, tears, urine, and fog, evoking a dissolution of control and leaking across borders associated with a pronounced anxiety toward the feminine. Elston and O'Garra experience desire as "a ceaseless yearning, the restlessness of waters washing against the floodgates of the soul" (ibid.). O'Garra kicks the German savagely in the face, and seeing "the stream of blood gush forth from the German's mouth," he bursts "into tears" ("GP," 27). Elston spits in the face of the German, whose own saliva will trickle down his chin later as he cowers in the hole ("GP," 25-6). The German prisoner seems almost entirely fluid--and feminine. He weeps; he calls out repeatedly for water; his sigh has a "liquidity of tone"; he reminds Elston of "all the beauty and music and rhythm of the Rhine"; and he seems ready to dissolve at any time into the mud ("GP," 31-2). The battlefield is also fluid, resembling a cosmic whirlpool--a vast, primal, devouring mother. In the heat of battle, "the earth was alive--afire. The earth was a mouth, it was a sea, a yawning gulf, a huge maw" ("GP," 19). Terms like "mouth, gulf, and maw" resonate with the threat of female genitalia. Indeed, O'Garra's own mouth suggests the monstrous feminine: "If one wished to know O'Garra, one looked at his mouth," the narrator comments ("GP," 9). O'Garra's mouth makes him "more than a man" and the false teeth clicking in his "ugly mouth" elicit a castrating potential, a vagina dentata ("GP," 8).

Desire in "The German Prisoner" expresses itself as contamination, pollution, threat: "There is a peculiar power about rottenness," Hanley insists, and O'Garra feels himself helpless before Elston's peculiar power. As their anxiety increases and they escalate their torture of the prisoner, the Tommies vent their "unclean" feelings through repeated references to defecation. In an obvious request for anal sex, Elston growls at O'Garra: "My arse on you. . . . Let's worry each other to death. Isn't that better than sitting here like soft shits. That time I fell asleep I did it in my pants" ("GP," 33). Elston calls O'Garra a "big shit house" as they stare at each other, transfixed with desire and rage ("GP," 35). Seeing the mangled body of the prisoner sink beneath the mud, O'Garra screams out, "I hate this thing so much I want to shite on it" ("GP," 36). Noting that "sexual fantasies played a large role in wartime propaganda," Mosse describes the "vogue" in Germany for "scatological postcards, uncensored because the fantasies were projected onto the enemy, depicted as covered with excrement, their bodies and even sexual organs exposed." 32 In Hanley's story, the abject body of the prisoner functions similarly as a field upon which both murderous aggression and transgressive desire can be projected and commingled. 33

The body of the German prisoner offers an acceptable outlet for the British soldiers' rage against their own victimization by a classist society. Their problems are not with any particular "Jerry" so much as with a society that considers them filth because of their class, race, or sexuality and sends them off to war to die. As he torments the prisoner, Elston asks him, "Why should you not suffer as well as us?" then repeats the words of his persecutor, Sargent Grundy--"Shit on you" ("GP," 25). Moreover, according to Eric Leed, such behavior announces the success of Elston's military training, in which the officer treats the recruit "the same way that he wants the soldier to treat the enemy in battle. To escape the low and painful status of victim," the soldier must identify with the aggressor. Such identification enables "the soldier's activity in war--all the shooting, maiming, and killing--to be perceived as moral, legitimate, and meaningful." 34 The complex system of division by which society operates becomes intensified in wartime, firmly fixing categories of good and evil. Because O'Garra and Elston do not initially blame the German prisoner for their predicament, we can see how "evil" is constructed and what it takes to assume the mantle of aggressor.

The men's increasing desire for each other provokes a corresponding intensification of their denunciations against the prisoner. Initially O'Garra condemns Elston for losing them in the fog, insisting that "its you and not this bloody Jerry who is responsible" ("GP," 26). When the German's sigh interrupts O'Garra's invective against Elston, O'Garra begins to refocus his rage, accusing the prisoner of being "as much to blame as anybody" ("GP," 27). Finally, he and Elston, far gone in their mutual seduction, decide that "That bastard lying there is the cause of all this," thus allowing them to transfer anxiety over illicit emotions to a safe object ("GP," 30). As soldiers, they have been taught to view the German as an acceptable target of violence and to consider murder as less transgressive than sex with another man. 35

Klaus Theweleit's analysis of narratives by the Friekorps--the "white troops" who graduated from postwar persecution of communists to the elite ranks of Hitler's S. S.--attempts to uncover systems of desire driving cultures of war and violence. He argues that versions of masculinity compel mastery of the body (sometimes through torture) to produce hardness and a destructive edge. Giving in to the female signifies "being swallowed, engulfed, annihilated. Women's bodies are the holes, swamps, pits of muck that can engulf." 36 The troops thus conceive their violence against women as "self-defense," a preemptive strike against a "threatening element," with the affective mode of such defense being "fear and desire" (MF, 183; italics in original).

"The German Prisoner" describes a similarly violent acting out of a simultaneously sexual and homicidal conflict. The feminine--including the enemy soldier--is marked as deviant and threatening, and must be destroyed. Accordingly, O'Garra and Elston objectify the German man as a "body," an "it": "With peculiar movements of the hands" they begin to "mangle the body" and to worry "it like mad dogs" ("GP," 32). Contact with the "youth's soft skin" and "the velvety touch of the flesh" leave Elston "infuriated," "demented," and "maddened" (ibid.). O'Garra and Elston use this body to bridge the gap of their repressed homosexual desire, relieving the pressure they feel by penetrating and puncturing the boy. O'Garra sticks his bayonet "up the youth's anus" and both insert a horse hair into his penis. Describing violent erotic murder by the Freikorps as "two male compulsions . . . tearing at the woman," Theweleit explains, "the man pushes the woman far away (takes her life), and gets very close to her (penetrates her with a bullet, stab wound, club, etc.)" (MF, 196). Once she has been reduced to a bloody mass, losing her "identity as an object with concrete dimensions and a unique name," the man can breathe a sigh of relief. . . .What we are dealing with here is the dissolution of the body itself, and of the woman as bodily entity as well as love object" (ibid.).

O'Garra and Elston, however, will not "breathe a sigh of relief" at the death of the boy, for the feminine also includes parts of themselves in conflict with rigidly structured ideals of masculinity that can be neither externalized nor destroyed. The bloody body of the boy operates successively as an impediment to the murderous rage and desire they feel for each other. The two decide to "bury this thing. . . . If we don't destroy him, he'll destroy us, even though he's dead" ("GP," 35). They "bury" the body by jumping up and down on it, trampling it beneath the mud, just as O'Garra has seen a Dublin woman trample a dog. Once the prisoner is gone, "their very beings" seem "to burst into flame," and they realize "there is no way out" ("GP," 36). They hurl themselves together, not realizing that the fog has lifted enough to reveal their position. After the smoke from an incoming shell has cleared, O'Garra can be seen with "tortured features," his eyes "gouged out, whilst beneath his powerful frame" lies "the remains of Elston" (ibid.). The pair is visible "for a moment only" before they sink into a common grave with their victim, "beneath the sea of mud" oozing "over them like the restless tide of an everlasting night" (ibid.).

According to Tim O'Brien, if you feel at the end of a war story that "some small bit of rectitude has been salvaged from the larger waste, then you have been made the victim of a very old and terrible lie." 37 Indeed, we see such a salvage operation in the "Introductory Note" to "The German Prisoner," written by Richard Aldington, author of war memoirs and the celebrated novel, Death of a Hero. Praising Hanley for the "force and vitality" with which he depicts "the unspeakable wrong . . . worked upon human souls by those who are supposed to be its guardians and guides," Aldington reconstructs O'Garra and Elston as suffering innocents who are "driven" and "tortured" to madness. Rounding up the usual suspects--old men and women distributing white feathers--Aldington rebuffs their objections to the "dreadfully dirty words" these characters use: "If you were not ashamed to send men into the war, why should you blush to read what they said in it? . . . Though the world will little note nor long remember what they did there, perhaps it will not hurt you to know a little of what they said and suffered." 38 In his insistence on what the men "said" and "suffered," Aldington himself seems to have difficulty remembering "what they did there." By refusing to acknowledge that they are rapists and murderers, Aldington recuperates a fantasy of sacrificial victims purified through suffering that works to perpetuate the mythology of war. 39

English military cemeteries of World War I are designed around a Cross of Sacrifice and a Stone of Remembrance hewn in the shape of an altar, projecting a Christian symbolism over rows and rows of identical graves and headstones whose uniformity is "reminiscent of wartime camaraderie." 40 Refusing such standard issue commemoration, Hanley chooses to remember the fallen differently. While in Hanley's description of O'Garra's disgust for his victim--"Everything I look at becomes Him. Everything Him"--the capitalized pronoun links the suffering of the German prisoner with the suffering of Christ, the re of Christ has been "plastered in shite" after "a five-nine landed behind it," pitching it "into one of the latrines" ("GP," 35, 13). Roadside crosses remind O'Garra of "the Irish Christ. All blood and tears," and he refuses to look at them, perhaps remembering his own persecution as an "Irish Christ" as well as a "shit house" ("GP," 13, 8). By establishing the connection between Peter O'Garra, Otto from Muenchen, and Jesus Christ, and by heaping them with shit, Hanley exposes the inevitable degradation of every person and every ideal that participates in the obscenity of war and forecloses the possibility of meaningful sacrifice.

"The German Prisoner" has been suppressed and ignored because its story of men achieving pleasure in brutality, murder, and self-destruction does not represent the way people have wanted to remember the war. According to the dominant narrative, only two legitimate manifestations of masculinity existed during World War I--heterosexuality and violence. Manliness required repeated acts of courage (violence) to "prove" heterosexuality, which nevertheless remained always in doubt. The myth that the love between men was limited to a transcendent, "chaste" homoeroticism sentimentalizes the compulsory heterosexuality behind an extreme form of masculinity that channels desire, rage, and fear into the savage murder of other men in battle. Comradeship in "The German Prisoner" cannot be separated from the horror of war because it is an essential ingredient of that horror. Hanley's profoundly disturbing memory of World War I raises powerful questions about the cost of unity during violent conflicts.

 


Anne Rice is a graduate student in English at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. She is currently working on issues of race, gender, class, and empire in American and British modernism.

Notes

1. Erich Maria Remarque, All Quiet on the Western Front, trans. A. W. Wheen (New York: Ballentine, 1982), 94. The ideas behind this essay come from a project for a seminar on "The Literatures and Cultures of World War One" taught by Jane Marcus at the CUNY Graduate Center in 1999. I would like to thank Jane for introducing me to the work of James Hanley and, as always, for her unflagging kindness and encouragement. I would also like to thank Cassandra Laity for her invaluable assistance in helping this essay take shape.

2. James Hanley, "The German Prisoner" (London, 1930), 30; hereafter abbreviated "GP."

3. Remarque, All Quiet, 94.

4. Jane Marcus, "Corpus/Corps/Corpse: Writing Bodies in/at War," in Arms and the Woman: War, Gender, and Literary Representation, ed. Helen M. Cooper, Adrienne Auslander Munich, and Susan Merrill Squier (Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1989), 163.

5. Samuel Hynes, A War Imagined: The First World War and English Culture (New York: Atheneum, 1991), 425. Hynes numbers the following texts among "the classic war books" published in 1929: All Quiet on the Western Front; R. C. Sherriff, The Journey's End; Richard Aldington, Death of a Hero; Robert Graves, Goodbye to All That; Ernest Hemingway, A Farewell to Arms; Ernst Junger, Storm of Steel; and Charles Carrington, A Subaltern's War. Texts for 1930 include Henry Williamson, Patriot's Progress; Siegfried Sassoon, Memoirs of an Infantry Officer; and Frederic Manning, Her Privates We.

6. Claire M. Tylee, The Great War and Women's Consciousness: Images of Militarism and Womanhood in Women's Writings, 1914-64 (Iowa City: University of Iowa Press, 1990), 256; hereafter abbreviated GW.

7. Paul Fussell, The Great War and Modern Memory (New York: Oxford University Press, 1975), 272; hereafter abbreviated GWM.

8. Although Hanley's work is little known today and his novels are largely out of print, his more famous contemporaries held his work in high regard. William Faulkner lauded Hanley's originality and style, calling his work, "not British, not American. . . . Just language like a good, clean cyclone." Frank G. Harrington, James Hanley: A Bold and Unique Solitary (Francestown, N.H.: Typographeum, 1989), 10. Calling him "a powerful writer," Alfred A. Knopf deemed Hanley's work "genuinely important." Linnea Gibbs, James Hanley: A Bibliography (Vancouver: William Hoffer, 1980), 128. In his introduction to the reissue of Boy (the novel confiscated and burned for obscenity along with "The German Prisoner"), Anthony Burgess remarks, "The geniuses who are neglected are usually the geniuses who disturb, and we do not like to be disturbed." James Hanley, Boy (London: Deutsch, 1990), vii. That Hanley was popularly regarded as a writer of some eminence is further illustrated by the title to his 1985 obituary in the Times, "The Neglected Genius of the Novel."

9. Harrington, James Hanley, 10.

10. Eric Leed, No Man's Land: Combat and Identity in World War I (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1979), 25.

11. Joanna Bourke, Dismembering the Male: Men's Bodies, Britain, and the Great War (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1996), 128-37; hereafter abbreviated DM.

12. George Mosse, Fallen Soldiers: Reshaping the Memory of the World Wars (New York: Oxford University Press, 1990), 77.

13. Margaret Higonnet, Jane Jenson, and Margaret Collins Weitz, eds., Behind the Lines: Gender and the Two World Wars (New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press, 1987), 3.

14. Sandra Gilbert, "Soldier's Heart: Literary Men, Literary Women, and the Great War," in Behind the Lines, ed. Margaret Higonnet et al.

15. Rebecca West, Ending in Earnest: A Literary Log (Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, Doran and Company, 1931), 77.

16. James Hanley, Broken Water: An Autobiographical Excursion (London: Chatto and Windus, 1937), 240-1.

17. Published during a boom in writing about World War I, "The German Prisoner" represents both an important document of wartime trauma and a powerful expression of postwar anxieties, particularly those suffered by the working-class veteran. "The German Prisoner" shares with Hanley's other work from the early 1930s (the eleven texts published between 1930 and 1934 that earned him the designation of proletarian writer) the theme of the individual in the throes of overwhelming extremity, often inflicted by brutal male authority res--employers, priests, teachers, fathers. Particularly compelling are Hanley's depictions of masculinity within the working-class immigrant family, as men who are brutally oppressed by other men struggle to preserve authority within their own homes.

18. Arguing that the disillusionment of the bourgeois volunteer constituted a "militarized proletarianization," Eric Leed observes that

in their reaction to the work-war, their resignation to meaningless, boring, endless, and dangerous jobs, many of the uniformed upper and middle classes took on the bitterness and resentment formerly identified with their social inferiors. This bitterness was directed at the 'managers' of war, the staff, as well as those at home who enjoyed 'security and comfort' and could not understand the suffering of the men at the front. [No Man's Land, 94]

19. Kevin C. Kearns, Dublin Tenement Life: An Oral History (New York: Penguin, 1994), 8-12. Tenants in tenements actually had less room than the law dictated should be allocated for livestock. Buildings intended for single-family use would have as many as eighty to one hundred residents, with only one toilet in the yard to service them all. As Kearns points out, investigative reporting and government studies from the turn of the century reveal conditions in which

it was common to find human excreta scattered about the yards and hallway passages. Privies and ashpits sometimes became infested with typhoid germs and yards were regularly flooded withstagnant water and waste creating an environment in which flies, insects and vermin thrived. . . . Multiple layers of decomposing wallpaper provided a perfect sanctuary for colonies of insects while rats as big as cats nested in rotting floor-boards and roamed freely at night, even entering the beds of nursing mothers and their infants, drawn by the scent of milk. [12]

The expectations of a soldier coming from this environment would be vastly different from a middle-class product of the public school system.

20. George Mosse describes modern masculinity's need for a countertype against which to define itself. In contrast to the civilized, highly controlled masculine ideal, men of certain ethnicity or sexuality are marked as uncivilized, feminine, and dangerously out-of-control. George Mosse, The Image of Man: The Creation of Modern Masculinity (New York: Oxford University Press, 1996), 55-76.

21. Liz Curtis, Nothing But the Same Old Story: The Roots of Anti-Irish Racism (London: Information on Ireland, 1984), 61.

22. Enda Duffy, The Subaltern Ulysses (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1994), 102.

23. In these early stories, the self-educated Hanley does not quite have control of his conventions, producing a wonderful unevenness that, paradoxically, enables him to get to what's really going on. According to Hanley's biographer, the author "was not uncritical of his . . . early work. Too many of the books were written too hastily, he said, under pressure to earn money" (Harrington, James Hanley, 26). Alan Ross says of Hanley's earliest pieces that Hanley "aimed, sometimes obliquely, sometimes directly, at transcription more than description." He is "a novelist who does not plan, who has no cut-and-dried story, but whose work is the journey back into his own consciousness." Alan Ross, introduction to The Last Voyage and Other Stories, by James Hanley (London: Harvill, 1997), xiv. Whether from lack of time or skill, or as a conscious technique, Hanley's work feels remarkably free of conventional dialogue--as if, says Jane Marcus, "he's recording real voices."

24. John Keegan, The Face of Battle (New York: Penguin, 1978), 45.

25. Ibid., 51.

26. "How funny," O'Garra tells Elston, "that in the moment I first realized your cowardice, I became conscious of my own strength. I must have pulled you a mile, you swine" ("GP," 21-2). While O'Garra means that he discovered unknown reserves of power, this episode marks the beginning of his dissolution. It is instructive to compare "The German Prisoner" to The Return of the Brute, a war memoir by Liam O'Flaherty, a proletarian Irish writer severely shell-shocked in the war. In O'Flaherty's novel, the cowardice of a young soldier infects a hardened Irish veteran named Private Gunn, prompting Gunn's descent into a madness that culminates in a suicidal attack in which he strangles his commanding officer, "uttering queer sounds" and mangling the body with his bare hands . The boy in O'Flaherty's story embodies the homoerotic ideal, with "pink cheeks, dazzling white teeth like a girl and big blue eyes" . Referred to frequently as a "woman" and a "girl," the boy reminds Gunn of his former wife, and his weakness feels like "seductive temptation" to Gunn . Liam O'Flaherty, Return of the Brute (London: Wolfhound Press, 1998). What interests me in both of these stories is how quickly these Irish soldiers lose their tenuous hold on masculinity and return to "the brute" when faced with a feminized English comrade.

27. Niall Ferguson, The Pity of War (New York: Basic Books, 1999), 349.

28. Trudi Tate, Modernism, History, and the First World War (New York: St. Martin's, 1998), 81.

29. Hynes, A War Imagined, 228.

30. Noting how often male love objects are described as blond, Fussell explains: "To be fair-haired or (better) golden-haired is, in Victorian iconography, to be especially beautiful, brave, pure, and vulnerable" (GWM, 275). Fussell also describes fair-haired German corpses as holding a tender fascination for many British soldiers (GWM, 276).

31. Jacqueline Rose's study of psychoanalytic accounts of war reveals a profound disturbance in that "seemingly secure distinction" between projection and reality:

If I project aggression on to the other, she or he is likely to become--in reality--the mirror or embodiment of the aggression I am trying to displace on to him or her. In other words, paranoid impulses don't just project on to reality as delusion; they affect reality and become a component of it. [28]

Given this scenario, asks Rose, "how can you recognize the real enemy. . . . Or rather, how can you distinguish, with absolute certainty, between your own projections and real external danger? If you produce the enemy, then you must t him" (28-9). Jacqueline Rose, Why War? Psychoanalysis, Politics, and the Return to Melanie Klein (Oxford: Blackwell, 1993).

32. George Mosse, Nationalism and Sexuality: Respectability and Abnormal Sexuality (New York: Howard Fertig, 1985), 128.

33. Carolyn Dean argues that only after the Great War, "when social commentators and analysts began to postulate a significant link between the wartime proliferation of pornography and the unprecedented violence of modern combat," did "pornography and violence become continuous with descriptions of assaults on the integrity of the human body" . She writes that many critics in the interwar period

no longer equate self-sacrifice with spiritual cleansing, but with spiritual degradation; the body has become enslaved by its own instincts, or more specifically, by a compulsive death-drive. . . . The war's degradation of men's dignity is red in the putatively emasculating and sexually pathological pleasure of humiliating and being humiliated, of exposing and being exposed. The war, in this view, had turned into a pretext for the satisfaction of other pleasures. [63]

Carolyn Dean, "The Great War, Pornography, and the Transformation of Modern Male Subjectivity," 3.2 : 59-72.

34. Leed, No Man's Land, 105-6.

35. Ferguson reports that "on occasions, and with encouragement from some commanders" British soldiers went into battle determined to take no prisoners . Even for those with no such intentions, it was difficult, in the words of one soldier, "once you start killing," to "turn a man off like an engine" (Ferguson, The Pity of War, 380). Ferguson contends that the "number of incidents is not as important as the impression they made on the culture of the trenches. Men magnified these incidents; they passed into trench mythology" on both sides, discouraging surrender and prolonging the war (ibid., 386). The episode with the prisoner belongs to "trench mythology"--except that Hanley's atrocity does not come from the other side.

36. Barbara Ehrenreich, introduction to Male Fantasies, by Klaus Theweleit (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1989), 1xiii; hereafter abbreviated MF.

37. Tim O'Brien, The Things They Carried: A Work of Fiction (New York: Houghton Mifflin, 1990), 31.

38. For an example of Aldington's salvage operation, see "At All Costs" in his Roads to Glory (1931; Freeport, N.Y.: Books for Libraries, 1970), which exemplifies the useless sacrifice of noble innocents. In this story, an officer--whom Aldington calls Hanley--suffers anguish as he prepares to carry out orders for a suicide mission in which he must sacrifice his own life and that of a subaltern. He is particularly anguished by the realization that while he will soon be "a mass of dead rotting decay," his wife will remain "young and beautiful and desirable" and eager to replace him in her bed . See Tate for a discussion of the hysterical repudiation of homosexuals as 'half-men' and 'scented worms'" articulated by Winterbourne in Death of a Hero and by Aldington himself in his personal correspondence (Tate, Modernism, History, 81-3).

39. Ferguson noted the paradox that while they were "weary of the war, men do not seem to have been weary of violence" (Ferguson, The Pity of War, 388). British veterans known as the "Black and Tans" carried out brutal assaults on Irish Republicans; their withdrawal initiated an even bloodier civil war. British troops used "extreme violence" in suppressing riots in Egypt in 1919 and revolts in Palestine and Iraq in 1920 in which "some 1,500 Egyptians were killed in the space of eight weeks, while in Iraq General Sir Aylmer Haldane even contemplated using poison gas" (ibid., 390). In "one of the most seminal atrocities of British imperial history," soldiers in Amritsar killed 379 people at a political meeting on 11 April 1919. The toll would have been greater if Brigadier-General Reginald Dyer "had been able to deploy two armoured cars with machine guns." The "techniques of mass murder patented on the Western Front" were now being exported for use in the colonies (ibid., 390-1).

40. Mosse, Fallen Soldiers, 83-4.

9.2 303-317

[Access article in PDF]

"You Must Join My Dead":
E. M. Forster and the Death of the Novel

Jesse Matz

Why did I stop writing fiction after The Passage came out? To that question there is no answer at all; I have been racking my brains and can find no reply to this very reasonable question. I can only suggest that the fictional part of me dried up.

E. M. Forster to Wilfred Stone, 18 February, 1966 1

Had Jane Austen not died at 42—had she lived instead to 90—she could have written twelve more books. Think what this would have done for English fiction: imagine Jane Austen refining the novel even beyond the fineness of Persuasion, seeing it through the hard years of the 1830s, heartening the Brontës, spoofing Dickens, cautioning the aesthetes, and even applying Darwin. Imagine such things and you have to regret the loss of those unwritten novels.

Austen's fans can say that only death could have stopped her—she who forced out work even as Addison's disease shook her pen. The same cannot be said about E. M. Forster, whose fans can only ask: why, if he lived to be 90, did he give up fiction at 45? In the second half of his life he could have written twelve more novels, too: imagine him bringing the wisdom of Howards End and A Passage to India to bear upon Indian independence, fascism, or the cold war; imagine him saving the English novel from its dwindling, or—and here is where so many of Forster's fans inquire more plaintively—fathering a gay literature. For he might have applied his vast moral and aesthetic resources to the problem of homosexuality. He might have given his rich Austenian inheritance to the culture of Stonewall, giving gay writing respectability and a crucial head start. Imagining that, gay readers in particular have to regret Forster's unwritten novels. And they do not even have death to blame.

Sometimes they blame something that shares death's deterrence. In his diary for 16 June, 1911, Forster writes of a "weariness of the only subject I both can and may treat—the love of men for women and vice versa". 2 In this and other such moments of disaffection readers have heard a worthy reason for Forster's refusal to write: a protest against compulsory heterosexuality. From 45 to 90, we might say, Forster did after all do something for the English novel: by not writing, he proved that one could not fit new gay life into old heterosexual forms, even if one were England's greatest living novelist.

For some readers, then, Forster's unwritten novels speak insurgent silence. Silence is no statement, however, for those who believe that Forster could have published gay novels had he only been brave enough—that he could have made a real political difference, and that "compulsory heterosexuality" really had little of death's deterrence. These other readers lay the blame elsewhere: like so many of his contemporaries, some say, Forster wanted to treat politics more directly, in a way fiction-writing could not; or he had finally found personal "equilibrium," and so lost the compulsion to write; or he just peaked early and then lived too long—made his mark, lost interest, and spent a long dotage enjoying his eminence grise. However much "the love of men for women & vice versa" may have wearied him, it alone did not drain his energy for fiction. The less dramatic truth here, it seems, is that what "dried up" the fictional part of him was various—variously composed of any number of resentments, changes, and alternative aspirations.

So it seems—however disappointing it is to give up on the more heroical and dramatic story of oppression, integrity, and forsaking. Unless we let a little piece of writing change our minds again. In the Forster collection at the Modern Archive Centre at King's College, Cambridge, there is a memoir Forster wrote in the years between 1922 and 1929—the years in which he finished writing A Passage to India and finished his fiction-writing career. In this memoir there is cause for Forster's desertion of fiction that has all anyone could ever want of drama: for it turns out, after all, to be a story of forbidden love, untimely death, and noble renunciation.

The memoir takes the form of a letter, to a young man Forster had met during his time in Egypt. This young man, Mohammed el Adl, had been Forster's lover until his death of tuberculosis in 1922. The "letter" Forster wrote to him is a sort of record of mourning, beginning in 1922 in the full flush of grief and ending after seven years' abatement have accomplished mourning's reparations. This transformation, however, is not one that the letter seems to welcome. Forster, it seems, wanted to refuse to mourn, because mourning would recast his strange and unnameable feelings for Mohammed as "love"; he found himself melancholy instead. In that mode, he was not fit for fiction, and no longer happy with its powers to turn one thing into another. His "letter" to Mohammed documents for us the development of what we might call melancholy realism—the generic mode that would, for the next 45 years, produce only unwritten novels.

In 1915, travel to Italy seemed dangerous, so Forster went to Alexandria instead. There he worked as a "Red Cross Searcher," questioning wounded soldiers about missing comrades. The work left him time to grow fond of the city, where he would stay not for the expected three months but for the duration of the war. He had not initially liked Alexandria. The place seemed "vastly inferior to India" and the natives like "mud moving, and exasperating in the extreme" (SLOEMF, I 233). But before too long he found cause to change his mind—in the "brown splendour" of boys swimming "naked and unrebuked" and in the larger diversity of the population (SLOEMF, I 237). Forster found that the cosmopolitan mixture of Alexandria's people symbolized "a mixture, a bastardy, an idea which I find congenial and opposed to that sterile idea of 100% in something which has impressed the modern world and forms the backbone of its blustering nationalism." 3 This change of heart partook of what would characterize Forster's fateful transformation; it predicted the change that would later make fiction-writing, too, sound like so much bluster.

Neither change would have taken place had Alexandria been what he had expected. Gertrude Bell, an expert on the region, had told him that he would have no opportunity to get to know the locals: according to Bell, "I should only see them in the streets as I went to and fro to work" (MBOEMF, 291). So Forster had not bargained for the encounter on the tram he took to and from work. The tram had Egyptian conductors, and one "fresh and sunny" morning in the spring of 1916 Forster looked up from his seat to see a conductor who made him think: "nice." 4 This conductor, it seems, was very young, and the only one who moved past passengers without stepping on their feet. He was charming; and so Forster made a point of taking his tram regularly. One cold winter night the conductor spoke: he asked Forster to get up, because his coat was under Forster's seat. The moment was pivotal: "You half saluted me at the Terminus after this if your tram came along, I half responded. Each knew the other wasn't someone else. No more"("M," 5).

This was eighteen-year-old Mohammed el Adl, native of Mansura, a butcher's son, who would soon risk his job to see to it that Forster would henceforth ride for free. Soon he would take Forster to what he called his "Home of Misery"—his "slum" home, where he kept his belongings all in a little trunk ("not much, but all clean") (SLOEMF, I 263). First—on their first night together—Mohammed took Forster to the Chatby Gardens, and then was sullen because Forster offered him cake. It seems he resented being bound to reciprocate. So he sneered and called the cake stale and said he was afraid it might poison him. But Forster won him over, calling him "gentleboy" ("M," 9), despite his caste, and making him smile. They went to the House of Misery; they went to Forster's rooms, and it was there that the "caresses started": "I think we had been playing chess. Then we reclined on the bed spread, I neared the wall. I touched your knee—you inclined toward me. . . Our first kiss follows . . ." ("M," 14). Despite the promising start things went badly. "For the rest, the evening was a muddle" ("M," 15): Forster made advances, Mohammed retreated and resisted, and things even got violent: "When I touched you again you defended yourself and hurt my hand. You didn't get off my bed, but wouldn't let me come near you and by accident I scratched your face. That sobered us" ("M," 15).

They laughed about it later, and eventually had less confused intimacy. But in a certain sense the whole affair was a muddle. Secrecy required meeting only every other week—and then the two soon had to part for good. Forster found Mohammed an army job that meant relocating and then Mohammed got married. Such obstacles could only limit the relationship and subject it always to random or fateful contingencies, keeping it from becoming anything we would really call a romance.

But this was just what Forster loved about his relationship with Mohammed. Random and fateful contingencies were the beauty of it. The muddle that followed the first kiss, for example, sounds disastrous, but to Forster it was wonderful because honest, rough, and real. Virtually every time he described Mohammed Forster dwells upon caprice, surprise, strangeness, even to the point of taking pleasure in ruin. Liking it when Mohammed sneers at his cakes; liking it also when "I asked you to remove your specs, because I found you more beautiful without them, and you refused irritably" ("M," 7-8); glad when Mohammed says, "I must be independent—if I do not want to meet you, I must say 'I do not,' if am not sure, I must be able to say 'perhaps'" (SLOEMF, I 271); pleased to note that Mohammed will sometimes refuse a kiss (calling him "foolish") but then at other times give "a kiss sudden and hard on the lips" ("M," 16); pleased with "an indescribable mixture of detachment and tenderness" (SLOEMF, I 272); and in general perfectly happy to do without romance. For what Forster valued here was what he himself called realism. Romance would have had coherence of feelings, effects, intentions; this relationship was all in the stray, purposeless, arbitrary detail. And every detail "sprang right from the judgment of a sincere heart," "so off the accredited lines . . . with so much cheerfulness in it," and "none of the solemnity which Christianity has thought essential to Romance" (SLOEMF, I 258). Some of the pleasure came simply from the departure from "respectability," the freedom from the standard plan. But it seemed to derive more essentially from a greater proximity to reality—almost as if Mohammed were a disproof of metaphysics.

It is therefore no surprise that Mohammed changed Forster's way of thinking. In a letter to Florence Barger describing the relationship, Forster explains how Mohammed's realism revamped ideals he had long held but never fully mastered. First, he emphasizes, in typical terms, the realism of this romance: "What I so value in him is his realism and solidity. He has heaps of romance but no sentimentality consequently" (SLOEMF, I 268). In what follows, Forster draws a connection between this realism and the refutation of racism:

Whenever I speak honestly he understands; and despite his maxim—"I find a certain amount of lies necessary to life"—is perfectly honest to me.—Does this read odd? It would read odder, indeed incredibly, to anyone who knew the country. Natives, especially of the lower city class, are dirty in body and mind, incapable of fineness, and only out for what they can get. This is the theory to which, after some reluctance, I had fully subscribed, and like all theories it has broken down. (SLOEMF, I 268)

On the one hand we have here an unimpressive change—from racism to condescension. But on the other hand we have an important view of the workings of truth, lie, and theory. What makes Mohammed proof that natives are not "incapable of fineness" strangely is his inconsistency. He lies; he is perfectly honest. That both are true means he is neither the "native" of racism nor that of romance. He is simply real, and this reality in him breaks down "theory," not just because it disproves the theory that natives are incapable of fineness, but because it disallows theory altogether. There is no way, it seems, to theorize about him, and that is what makes him both captivating and instructive.

A similar effect follows Forster's extrapolation of his happiness to that of others:

. . . it is such a triumph over nonsense and artificial difficulties: it is a sample of the other triumphs that I am sure come off but of which we hear nothing through the brassy rattle of civilisation so called; triumphs varying greatly in form, but in spirit all the same. When I am with him, smoking or talking quietly ahead, or whatever it may be, I see, beyond my own happiness and intimacy, occasional glimpses of the happiness of 1000s of others whose names I shall never hear, and know that there is a great unrecorded history. (SLOEMF, I 269)

Just as Mohammed's inconsistencies debunked "theory," the specificity of the pleasures he produces dispel historical generality. Recorded history tells only of the sort of love one hears about. But sensitive now to the terms of "real" love, Forster develops an ear for "whatever it may be"—for unheard of happinesses, felt in forms too various to fit the forms provided. Once again it is as if Forster had come upon a new style of experience. This is not just something he has never done before, but something different in kind, like a new medium.

This is to say that Mohammed meant not only a change from celibacy to sexuality, and not only an initiation into homosexuality, but an epistemological change—a change of mode. This shift is embodied, in a sense, in something Mohammed said to Forster to brush him off at the moment of that muddled first kiss. Forster, it seems, had taken Mohammed's erection as a sign of interest, but Mohammed said, "My damned prick always stands up whoever it is, it means nothing" ("M," 16). The meaninglessness here is all: like inconsistency, like unrecordable history, it indicates nothing larger, and is therefore at once pure pleasure and real information. It is important to notice here exactly what drew Forster's interest, and what therefore ultimately drew it away from his novels' style of creativity: not homosexuality as opposed to heterosexuality; not the freedom to engage in and speak of love for men; but rather a way of "connecting" that wholly dispenses with predetermined feelings and acts, doing things instead according to the radical feel of the moment and the real needs of body and soul. This radical realism would naturally have presented itself in homosexual relations, because these would have had less predetermined about them, but the sexuality Forster valued so much here had much less to do with object-choice and much more to do with contingency, spontaneity, and caprice.

It might seem foolish to stress radical realism here, given the fact that Forster fits Mohammed fairly crudely into what we call the "romance of alterity," that exoticism whereby Westeners pretend at love for those "others" they conquer. Is this not a colonialist fantasy? Is not the Egyptian boy to the British man what the colonies were to the crown—something subordinate, phantasmal, and exploited? This sort of sexual adventure, in which license suspends the responsibility required of relationships at home, and cultural stereotypes encourage a man to dream up his own delightful opposite, happened all around Forster at this moment, making it perhaps strange to say that for him the romance was real. But it is the aftermath that justifies the claim here, for Forster does not just get in and then get out: had his cultural life persisted as before despite his sexual adventure, Forster might have been but a sexual imperialist; but the change that follows proves that Mohammed's alterity had very real effects not only on Forster himself but on the literary culture to which he had already become indispensable.

What became of Mohammed's mode of realism when he died? How do you mourn for someone who "meant nothing"? How, that is, do you feel grief as such when what you have lost was something you enjoyed not having? These are the questions that Forster's "letter" to Mohammed exists to answer. And the answers explain why Forster stopped writing fiction.

The letter is an elegy. It uses the conventions of elegy to structure and work through grief. But it is only ostensibly elegiac—or only elegiac once it gets to its ending. At first, and principally, it forestalls and refuses mourning. Its mode is different: it refuses to let go of the particulars that made Mohammed so wonderfully meaningless. In so doing it trades mourning for melancholy. Mohammed's sexuality had been one of pragmatic realism. Forster loved it, and took it on, but then grief made it recalcitrant. Its attachment to real detail became a melancholy refusal of unreality—a refusal of the fictions of healthy mourning, and ultimately a refusal of fiction itself.

In the beginning of 1919—three years before Mohammed's death—Forster left Alexandria. In the preceding months, he had visited Mansurah and found Mohammed in tough shape, fatigued from long hours in the cotton markets and already beginning to suffer from the disease that would kill him. But in the years that followed the relationship went on in its original mode. It was, as before, what time, circumstances, and mood permitted, and not much more. From 1919 to 1922, Forster would help Mohammed in what ways he could; often he would long to be with him, but never did he think of the relationship as anything primary or deep. Distance and dying did nothing to strengthen the bond; rather, it helped Forster persevere in unsentimentality and to correct lapses from realism : "Very difficult to know what the lover is like—or rather how he feels and behaves toward the lover. Determined my life should contain one success I have concealed from myself and others M's frequent coldness to me. And his occasional warmth may be due to politeness, gratitude, or pity. The prospect of his death gives me no pain" (D, 11 May 1922). What sounds callous is in fact deeply considerate: it is Forster admitting that he has tried to falsify Mohammed, to make of him a fiction of "success," and resolving now to affirm the reality. Frequently in these weeks Forster worries about feeling "love": writing things like "latterly my great love prevents my feeling that he is real" (D, 7 May 1922), Forster discovers the odd conflict between love and realism and has to t to keep the former from taking over.

So what begins to emerge, in these months before Mohammed's death, is a sort of rift: there are the truths about Mohammed, made up of his frequent coldnessess and other refusals, and endorsing an outlook so rich in reality; and then there are the fictions of success, love, and romance, made up by Forster himself when indulgent or lazy or when he wanted to tell himself and others a more satisfying story. On one side, the realism; on the other side, the fictionality. The two pressed apart even beyond their long-standing opposition, and did not allow for the sort of reconciliation, also long-standing, which has allowed writers in particular to say that fiction produces reality. For no such philosophies could really distract Forster from his love for the way Mohammed evaded him.

Once Mohammed died the rift widened; the "reality" receded, sharpening Forster's longing for it. This sharpened longing prompted the letter to Mohammed. And it was the source of the letter's strange characteristic feature: its approach to grief. Wanting to resist fictions of love and to maintain a sense of Mohammed's reality, Forster refuses to undergo mourning. He refuses, that is, to accept the loss, but this does not mean that he pretends Mohammed has not died, or that he does not care. Rather, it means that he does not allow mourning to transform the brutal real fact of death. The best example of this refusal, as we shall see, is the way he dwells upon the grotesque reality of Mohammed's decomposing corpse. The counterpart to the pleasure Forster had taken before in Mohammed's reality, this new realism has the character of what we call melancholy.

In a paper published the year Forster met Mohammed, Freud described melancholia as a pathological stopping-short before mourning. In his account, melancholy occurs when the ambivalence natural to the love-relationship becomes, after the death of the beloved, a form of self-reproach: the melancholic's ambivalence becomes a kind of anger directed against the self—even to the point where the self might "consent to its own destruction" in suicide. 5 The dynamic Freud describes takes place almost willfully in Forster. His ambivalence about the love-relationship was, as we have seen, something he cultivated. And it very directly became self-reproach in his determination to stay ambivalent: whenever Forster scolds himself for pretending his relationship with Mohammed was a sure thing, he directs anger against himself in the Freudian fashion. Of course he never does so to the point of "consenting to his own destruction." But does he not perhaps consent to the destruction of "the fictional part of me"? That is, might not Forster's melancholy have directed destructive anger against its enemy—the fictions of romance which, especially in mourning, would have worked through what had been so rapturously unworkable? Melancholia overdevelops the conscience, or that faculty through which we subject ourselves to critical scrutiny. Forster, in his melancholic response to Mohammed's death, overdeveloped his writerly conscience to the point where it regarded his fictional self with a too-factual and withering skepticism.

Mohammed died with Forster knowing only vaguely how and when and not knowing what grief would follow. The grief surprised him, by coming only after a delay: he got confirmation of Mohammed's death on 27 June, 1922, passed a month in the sort of "painless" apathy he had been feeling before, but then felt that apathy transform. On 5 August, compelled by some ever-worsening "oppression," he began to write out that apathy's transformation into melancholy and beyond.

Forster begins the letter worrying he will get things wrong and falsify Mohammed's realism. Since "now you are not here to correct me when I think of you not as you are but as I should like to think of you" ("M," 13), Forster risks writing not fact but fiction, and he therefore seems to resolve from the beginning to "correct" himself as far as possible. This means, paradoxically, pretending that Mohammed is still with him. He denies the fact that "you are not here": "I write it with my mind on you and with the illusion that your mind still exists and attends" ("M," 3). But to have both the realism (which requires Mohammed's attention) and the truth (which means his death) Forster has to strike a strange compromise: "I pretend that you are still alive, because it is only thus that I can think of you as real, although I know that a putrid scrap in the Monsourah burial ground is all that was you" ("M," 3). In a harrowing double-bind, Forster finds that being true to Mohammed means thinking of his corpse; consistency compels grotesque visions, and Forster's realism goes gothic. It also begins to seem unspeakable. The melancholy of dwelling on the reality of the dead begins now to put Forster out of patience with language itself, for language takes the side of falseness, mourning, and fiction, against the finer truths of sex, decay, melancholy, and fact.

We see all this right away as Forster tries in his letter to record the relationship's initial moments. He writes of his first glimpse of Mohammed aboard the Bogos tram; of trying to catch that same tram on subsequent days; Mohammed's polite ways with passengers, the night he first spoke to Forster, and the day in March of 1917 when he said, "You shall never pay" ("M," 5). He writes of these things but then breaks off and pauses to voice what will become his letter's perpetual dissatisfaction:

Mohammed I try to keep this real, but my own words get in the way, and you are decayed to terrible things by this time—dead six months. I do not mind that, but I fear you becoming unreal, so that all our talks together and the occasional nights we have slept in one bed will seem to belong to other people. So I can't write this letter to you long. It is an effort for you are not even a ghost now and I am invoking my own memories. Dear boy, I want those memories to be of you, not stained by me. I do not want to prate of perfect love, only to write of you as if you are real. So I try to think of you in your grave sometimes. It is real, and contemporary with me, it leads me back to the real you. ("M," 6--7)

What leads Forster back to Mohammed is not writing about him: in other times and places writing might have the power to evoke and to recall, but here it is just "prating," as if writing cannot help but fall into the sort of standard patterns that tell of perfect love. Writing can only "belong to other people," because it cannot help but obey convention. What leads back to Mohammed—to that reality he so richly embodied—is the mere intractable, unspeakable fact of his corpse, terrible in decay but wonderful still in singularity. Here there is of course a problem for a writer. To some degree, the dilemma is eminently typical: it is the problem, most notably, of those approaches to language and meaning that emphasize the gaps that come between realities and our words about them—of poststructuralist philosophies, most recently, and of the modernist theories that came before them. But the problem troubles Forster in peculiar ways, with unique results.

For it is, first of all, a very specific reality that seems unavailable to writing: it is the reality of sexual desire free of any story, free of "perfect love" or "grande passion" as any sexuality would plot it. Moreover, the fact that the reality is unavailable to writing is, in this case, not at all welcome. No poststructuralist avant la lettre, Forster sees no playful advantage in the sort of gap he discovers here. His liberalism commits him instead to strong belief in communicative rationality. And it keeps him from becoming what other modernists similarly awakened had become. Whereas Joyce, for example, pressed the quest for new reality into linguistic dislocation, Forster had too much esteem for norms of public speech to violate them as far as he would have to have done to clean them of their "stain." So what results for Forster—from this sexualized obsession with "reality," from his consequent problem with words—is a unique form of writing. When he says, "I cannot write this letter to you long," he refers to a very strange new choice of mode: he will not write at length, but only in short bursts, as if to try to use language just enough to invoke Mohammed but not long enough to make him begin to "become unreal." And these short bursts of writing will perpetually turn on themselves, curtailing whenever writerly momentum starts to carry them away.

The unique result of Forster's grief, in other words, is a strange melancholic form of writing. In the short run, this melancholic form produced the letter to Mohammed, a document unusual for its very slow accretion of short bits: written over the course of seven years, the letter nevertheless amounts to only twenty manuscript pages, with short passages dwarfed by the passage of time intervening between them. In the long run, this melancholic form seems to have brought Forster to a kind of silence analogous to the letter itself: what fictions Forster might have begun curtailed themselves instantly, washing back into "reality," and leaving ever longer spaces of time between them.

This silence appears in the letter as a strong anti-linguistic caution. Forster sounds like a man walking a thin line, for as he notes "one slip of my mind would fake a spook of you" ("M," 12): one slip into fiction would falsify; Mohammed would become a romantic spirit, and the love story would get written. So Forster uses his words very sparingly—typically to note in gnomic phrases the times and ways Mohammed disallowed love. We get short references to muddles, irritations, refusals, always with the knowledge that "if I miss things like these you will not be real" ("M," 8). Getting a feel for these gnomic phrases and their justification, one develops an ear for the silence that characterizes the second half of Forster's career: both have a sort of gruff resignation, trying to indicate without words something better than fiction; and both defer to the pragmatic mode of nonfiction that would become Forster's exclusive kind of writing. You can hear the Forster who gave up fiction in the Forster who writes these fragments. Moreover, you can hear the protest—so compelling for the way it mixes grief, desire, and regret; so sorry for its loss of literary faith and its new sullen brutality; so much like Forster trying to be Proust, sounding more like Hemingway, and on the way out of the business altogether.

But the most poignant thing of all here is Forster's inability to keep it up. Years of melancholy keep him laconic and austere and able to express himself in the mode appropriate to Mohammed's pragmatic sexuality; but as years pass, melancholy does give way to mourning, and fiction-writing ensues after all. The change is poignant because it finds Forster regretting his relative contentment: at first he is melancholy and grotesque and taciturn but true; as time goes on, and constructive mourning becomes possible, things become brighter and fonder but false, and Forster knows to regret the loss of realism that comes as a consequence. It is as if he had found, in spite of himself, the truest way to write, and then lost the knack even as he regained his equanimity. The irony of that give-and-take could only redouble his suspicion of fiction-making.

Here is how the letter to Mohammed documents the change in question. On page thirteen of the letter Forster writes of his great regret that words get in the way, still worrying about losing Mohammed's reality. On the three or four pages that follow, he describes that first muddled sexual encounter—the one that left Mohammed with a bloody eye. Next come hopes dashed—hopes for more extensive sexual intimacy disappointed by distance and illness, but, again, with fascination for the honest realities these failures involved. Then Mohammed suddenly becomes a fading memory. It is not possible to fix dates, or to know for sure how much time has passed since Mohammed's death or between installments, but Forster writes, "months have gone by since I wrote the above. You are dimmer. I knew it would happen" ("M," 17). The change seems unavoidable—the inevitable result of passing years and the way they must make even the most graphic realities unreal. Forster, however, suggests that something else has been responsible for letting unreality in. That something is a sort of epistemological paradox: when Mohammed's reality was fresh, Forster could not write about it at length for fear of falsifying it into a fiction; now that Mohammed has faded, however, and that danger no longer seems so great, Forster lacks the written record necessary to serve as a reminder. At this point Forster writes, "I shall never describe every moment of our intercourse, as I had hoped" ("M," 17). The regret here runs up against the paradox in question, whereby description then would have been but a rewriting of those moments of intercourse, but could have served now as the best hope for accurate recollection. Between that then and this now Forster seems to locate fiction's failure. As he builds towards the finish of the memoir-writing, finally, "you must join my dead" ("M," 19)—he seems to finish writing something that is much less an elegy for Mohammed and much more an elegy for the vocation that has so gracelessly let him down.
