Of these revelations and others, Farr's narrator remarks: "Poor Jacklin [the heroine] woke to this situation in the year 1904, long before the women's movement had any driving power behind it" (SJ, 74). This date is not meant to be comically ironic, although it sounds that way to us; during the years Pound knew her (1909-12), Farr was rather cheered by feminism's driving power for social and political change.

This novel is dedicated "To the Man Who Shall Be," suggesting that a subject position like New Man should follow upon the New Woman. But the novel also sits in judgment of the reckless female main character for her disparate variety of yearnings—Fabian, independent, decadent, woman as "the slave of emotion" (SJ, 241). The novel ends with the remarriage of the original couple after various overheated flings and a child from one of those flings sitting with them: "husband and wife looked at each other with eyes full of mutual charity" (SJ, 248). Thus Farr's Ibsenish opinions were rather tempered by a narrative compromise around the marriage plot engineered by the author—hardly a totally radical solution.

It is probably irrelevant to discuss Farr's Modern Woman: Her Intentions at any length because the sheer fact of a fervent, public feminist book stating "This is to be the Woman's Century" only two years before Pound wrote his poem may be all we need to appreciate his work of interpretive erasure in the making of the poem. 34 Or, at best, we can take the poem as indicating in encoded metaphors his view of Farr's declamations on marriage, prostitution, the vote, economic independence, love, divorce, and chosen motherhood as passéist trappings, possibly what is referred to as "strange spars of knowledge," "some curious suggestion," and "fact that leads nowhere." At the very least, her book touches topically upon many of the political, social, personal, and moral issues of this central period of feminist struggle. Farr's book is an enthusiastic polemic on many topics, but especially on how the t against the "prisons" that keep women trapped is larger than the vote, and how such struggles will transform social life within modernity (MW, 93).

Nonetheless, a glance at her introduction alone offers some sense of Farr's particular politics. It is spoken from a patrician, aristocratic, explicitly "white" feminism, and tied to the medieval courtliness of white men, who have had their historical day in the sun as knights and troubadours. They are imagined by her as ting inspired by "their ladies' colours"—as if all of medieval life were a defense of Western women or done in their name—a peculiar position at best (MW, 12). "White men have fought in the past [against what it is not said, although to honor women is strongly implied], and it remains for white women to t now, and at last rid their sex all over the world of the ignominy of this false doctrine" (ibid). This "false doctrine" refers to Semitic patriarchal institutions, since the enemy of women's freedom is the "Semites" (Jews and "Mohammedans"—i.e. Muslims), whose patriarchal control of women was inexplicably reexpressed in Christianity. Farr claims that the world-historical problem at the root of women's oppression is that "the white races adopted the Assyrian Semite's Scriptures" (MW, 8). This snarl of scapegoating, Semiticized representations, patrician racism, and feminism is worth more than the cursory glance I give it here, but her general position is clear. Feminism offers a powerful "alchemy" to ignite the modern world, transmuting its institutions and revaluing its values, but the world doesn't yet much credit this "fire that is to burn it" (MW, 7). If this book is any indication, at age fifty, Farr's outspoken, intellectually wayward fire was rather undimmed.

Pound's poem shows a fascinated ambivalence toward the creative power and political bite of Farr, both as a New Woman, and as a serious, respected contributor to a Yeats-centered poetry scene, and, before that, to a Shaw and Ibsen-centered theater scene that was generally encoded as "feminist." The real re has been transformed from a critical, powerful, influential, outspoken, and original historical woman into a textual "femme"—one form of a muse of modernism—an inadequate, anonymous, and displaceable female re. Hardly static or a dilettante, though a woman of many interests, Florence Farr—artist, actress, thinker, and performer—has been rather startlingly recast by Pound. His poem portrays Farr as empty and "second always," instead of a formidable cultural activist, her fervent female striving interpreted as a seaweedy trap or "slow float," and her energetic social criticism a useless backwater. 35 All in all, Pound's poem is a mechanism in the service of one kind of male subjectivity—the active creation of a shallow but provocative female muse for the containment of historical New Woman effervescence and achievement. This is an important move in the relationship of modernism to modernity. By representing a female re in this way, Pound has contained, grounded, or stalled consideration of the impact-laden presence and agency of the "real person" on whom the poem was based, making the re an Old Woman with useful muse properties, an exemplum of old stuff that still somehow inspires. Poetic representation masters this female re, using poetic institutions like "muse" in order to deflect attention away from the historical achievements of Farr, the hidden subject.

What else could be at stake here? To answer, I must assume that the "over-elaborate post-Browning "'Imagiste' affair"—a poem that Pound sent to Harriet Monroe in August 1912—is this same "Portrait d'une Femme." 36 If this phrase does describe "Portrait d'une Femme," it marks a curious conflicting transition in his poetry—for how could something be at once "over-elaborate" and "Imagiste'" given those "few rules" of imagism, a movement invented circa December 1912 and elaborated in those well-known dicta early in 1913? "Portrait d'une Femme" is arguably the precise opposite of imagist work: it is an indirect treatment of "the thing," saturated with adjective and repetition far beyond condensed efficiencies of "the presentation," and composed not in forward-looking, musical free verse, but using a pentameter "metronome." 37 Given this symptomatic conflict between statement and poem, what else is at stake? The pressure from futurist polemicist Filippo Marinetti. 38 His work was available in London from 1910, when he presented his ideas at the Lyceum Club and in 1912, when a March lecture on futurism was given the same day that Pound delivered his second lecture on the troubadours, concerning Arnault Daniel. 39 In a "careerist" reading, Litz and Lawrence Rainey propose that the enormous 1912 success of Marinetti's avant-garde proposals and affronts, in contrast to Pound's work in "literary culture" as "a restricted aristocracy of sensibility," directly motivated imagism's invention. 40 To make his cultural mark, they argue, Pound felt he had to construct some distinctive, audacious product, and not simply that which embodied and represented the cultural heritage of the past. The poem expresses this debate.

The "femme" is surrounded in her pool of debris with all the cultural materials that kept Pound from being perfectly modern in the audacious Marinetti sense: a lack of an "aggressive character," an attachment to beauty, a "pensive immobility," and stasis (rather than "speed"). A whole past of beautiful but waterlogged cultural goods swirls around this re—goods by which Pound was insistently and overwhelmingly tempted, but that were ultimately cast away in millennial futurist provocations: "we will destroy the museums, libraries. . . . will t moralism, feminism . . ." 41 To rid himself of the "museum"-quality goods that make culture soggy, Pound attributes them to the "femme," finds them damaged although tempting, and then wards them off in the "No!" and "Nothing." To possess these materials is to be swamped by culture as it was, to be able to have nothing that's "quite your own." The double move of identification with the materials and rejection of them is contradictory, of course; this contradiction is a coiled spring giving the poem power. No matter that Farr's own personal culture (as a real individual) may have been as modern (in her feminism) as it was retro (in her medievalism). This was exactly the kind of synthesis Pound used to desire, but now had to reject in order to position himself as adequately, truly modern from not quite modern enough.

Thus the poem is described proleptically as "post-Browning" although it is not at all beyond Browning—it is Browningesque, imitated after Browning, and "post-" only in that sense. The poem is described as "Imagiste" although it is not imagiste at all; it is rather rhetorically "over-elaborate." Hence this lack of fit between his description and his poem is itself precise evidence of the tension between Pound's "Victorian modernism" and his desires for a diction-cleansing, culture-purging rupture in some emphatic mode. 42 The inaccurate description both exposes his inadequate modernism and is an act of dislodging to rectify that inadequacy. To acknowledge the old muse, to establish his career power, to scapegoat her materials even as he is tempted, to cast her off in the last lines as unoriginal—these are vital accomplishments.

Furthermore, if it is possible—and it is not unlikely—that in hearing Marinetti's ideas, Pound might have caught wind of the "disprezzo della donna," this program might have focused his attitude toward his "femme." The part of Marinetti's program called "scorn for woman" is an "ideological double helix," in Janet Lyon's words (M, 101). If Marinetti meant "scorn" for the bourgeois, romantic ideology of Womanhood with all the conservative, madonna-esque or feminine manipulations that implies, his phrase could betoken feminist critique of the gender system. If he meant scorn for women as actual people standing in the way of the sleek automotive purgations by violence that his manifesto enacted, or scorn for the effeminate in men, then such scorn had ideological implications in the building of muscular modernist claims by strategic attacks on specific women, on women's activism, and on transgressive gender ideas. This poem, arguably registering Marinetti's interventions, although hardly as slashing, over-stated, or absolute as Marinetti's claims, could be described as Pound's soft-core scorn. In "Portrait d'une Femme," Pound makes the past (his past) passéiste by putting it into a female site of entrapment, revealing the enormous temptation of this site, and finally by rejecting that past.

Pound's particular modernism, soon to be under war pressure, as well as being already under New Woman pressure and pressure from alternative, transgressive sexualities, is gradually coming to be parallel with non-effeminate maleness. Despite the enormous contemporaneous critical thinking on this issue, one kind of masculine sensibility—"the real sperm of them"—triumphs within his thinking. Propounding this maleness is part of Pound's notable achievement during this period; it is probably one of his most culturally influential acts within the reception of modernism as well as its production. 43 One part of Pound's constructed maleness is sustained, though not without unevenness, by various short and long-term strategies working against the acknowledgment of women as coequal and co-temporal producers of artistic and critical works; yet he evinces a good deal of conflict in relation to any specific woman. As we have seen at length, in this poem the trace of the female re as coequal and co-temporal is reduced, which is rather startling when the nature and opinions of the "real woman," Florence Farr, are considered.

The poem is the mechanism for the imaginative, and possibly real, consolidation of a male poetic subjectivity as modern by the mellow, "reluctant" disparaging of a female cultural producer, whom Pound perceives as a rival and as a backwater, in two different, conflicting narratives involved with fellow male artists: the "Yeats" (and "Shaw") narrative, and the "Marinetti" narrative. Making a historical woman coequal into a poetic muse thins her, controls her agency and impact, evokes the past of poetry as an institution around her, voids her critical Ibsen-inspired interventions into issues of gender, avoids her accomplishments as a performer and musician, and reduces her own modernity to a retro backwater. Indeed, as a cultural institution of poetry used by a modernist, the muse is a mechanism that takes a modern subject—a New Woman—and changes her into an encumbered, static, non-modern subject. The poem moves Farr backward, setting her "scores" of years behind her own historical time and achievements, creating female belatedness from a woman pioneer in order to consolidate a male pioneer from a man's sense of his own belatedness. The resistance to acknowledging females as modern subjects (a denial of historicity noted by Rita Felski) may be said to begin in Anglo-American modernism with poems such as this one.

Pound wittily and carefully uses the poetic conventions of the lyric—the muse re inside the apparatus of poesis—to construct a passive retro muse, a female re from an active, provocative influence in historical time. Pound uses poetic convention to protect himself from historical shifts around gender. One can see that his poetic career is forged from intricate cross-and intra-gendered power interactions that include among them friendship, mentoring, misogyny, sex-radical thinking, male potency, sexual hopes and fantasies, and male panic, all of which play against and are inflected by poetic subject positions such as muse. The ultimate purpose of a feminist and historical examination of poetic texts is to change the terms and understandings of poetry definitively, placing issues of gender, the apparatus of poesis, and power-oriented production and reception centrally in play. Asking gendered questions of the ideologies and social situations of poetry as a mode of practice constitutes an opening into the deepest apparatus of poesis.

 


Rachel Blau DuPlessis is Professor of English at Temple University. Her Genders, Races, and Religious Cultures in Modern American Poetry, 1908-1934 (Cambridge University Press) appeared in 2001. Drafts 1-38, Toll (Wesleyan University Press), part of her long poem project, also appeared in 2001.

1. This sentence is indebted to Jonathan Culler's recent remarks about an argument by Steven Knapp: "a text has literary interest insofar as our interest in it exceeds our interest in ring out what the author intends." Jonathan Culler, "The Literary in Theory," in What's Left of Theory? ed. Judith Butler, John Guillory, and Kendall Thomas (New York: Routledge, 2000), 280.

2. Susan Wolfson, Formal Charges: The Shaping of Poetry in British Romanticism (Stanford, Calif.: Stanford University Press, 1997), 19.

3. Rachel Blau DuPlessis, Genders, Races and Religious Cultures in Modern American Poetry, 1908-1934 (New York: Cambridge University Press, 2001), 9-12. This paper on Pound is part of a several-chapter essay, the rest of which will be appearing in Modern Language Quarterly in 2003.

4. This phrase is from Rita Felski, Beyond Feminist Aesthetics (Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1989), 175. Felski generally does not speak about poetry, however, which is my interest here.

5. "Women are the 'Muses' whom genius has kissed, just as man, the genius, has been 'kissed by the Muse,'" notes Meret Oppenheim carefully, trying to analyze the impact on a woman artist, of just such a stolid convention. "Acceptance Speech for the 1974 Art Award of the City of Basle, January 16, 1975," in Meret Oppenheim: Defiance in the Face of Freedom, ed. Bice Curiger (Cambridge, Mass.: MIT Press, 1989), 130. Lisa Rado observes that "the ways in which writers have portrayed the source of their inspiration can serve in part as a reflection of literary and cultural history," also linking "third-sex" theories in sexology with what she calls the androgyne muse. Lisa Rado, The Modern Androgyne Imagination: A Failed Sublime (Charlottesville: University Press of Virginia, 2000), 2.

6. Svetlana Boym, Death in Quotation Marks: Cultural Myths of the Modern Poet (Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1991), 192-200, and Barbara Johnson, The Feminist Difference: Literature, Psychoanalysis, Race, and Gender (Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1998), 127.

7. Dorothy Dinnerstein, The Mermaid and the Minotaur: Sexual Arrangements and Human Malaise (New York: Harper and Row, 1976).

8. Jed Rasula, "Gendering the Muse," Sulfur 35 : 159-75. Pound's tactic in this poem cuts against Rasula's model, for Pound mainly rejects, despite its temptation, the female "voice" "pre-articulated inside him" .

9. Ibid., 160.

10. Theodor Adorno, "On Lyric Poetry and Society," in Notes to Literature, vol. 1, trans. Shierry Weber Nicholsen (New York: Columbia University Press, 1991), 37-54; hereafter abbreviated "OLP."

11. Indeed, Hugh Grady faults these readings for "lack of [a New Critical] sense of the materiality of signifiers . . . and the complex relations of individual words in the poem . . . producing a moment at which Adorno—who ranks for me as perhaps the greatest of twentieth-century critics/theorists—unaccountably sounds like a mere inspired literary impressionist." Hugh Grady, "Further Notes on Marxism(s) and the Lyric," in New Definitions of Lyric: Theory, Technology, and Culture, ed. Mark Jeffreys (New York: Garland, 1998), 192-3.

12. Some terms from Abigail Solomon-Godeau, Male Trouble: A Crisis in Representation (London: Thames and Hudson, 1997).

13. I use the term "foundational cluster" in my "'Corpses of Poesy': Some Modern Poets and Some Gender Ideologies of Lyric," in Feminist Measures: Soundings in Poetry and Theory, ed. Lynn Keller and Cristanne Miller (Ann Arbor: University Of Michigan Press, 1994), 69-95, an essay that appears in revised form as a chapter in Genders, Races and Religious Cultures. I am bracketing the Sapphic "invention" of the lyric, given the fact that some of the originary lyrics in Western culture are written by a woman quite often to female objects of desire. I am also bracketing the issue in the history of poetry and other arts: in myth, muses once were practitioners of their art and the artist seen as an inspired conduit. The question of when this model shifted to represent muses as conduits and artists as inspired practitioners enlarges the theoretical and historical questions of gender and art.

14. Ezra Pound, Personae (New York: New Directions, 1926), 61; all references to "Portrait d'une Femme" are taken from this edition.

15. Barrett Watten, "What I See in 'How I Became Hetty Jones,'" Poetics Journal 10 (June 1998): 107.

16. One can hardly avoid seeing this poem as similar to T. S. Eliot's "Portrait of a Lady," which expresses the speaker's desire to separate from a maternal and genteel re of entrapment and apparently amateur status. However, it is unlikely that Pound knew of this Eliot poem when he wrote his; in 1912 the Eliot poem existed only in manuscript. The two poets did not meet until 1914. Marianne Moore's 1917 "Monkeys"—with its puma or lynx speaking bitterly about animal-human power relations (possibly a gender allegory), and its ending about the sea's shocking deposits of debris—seems to be an oblique commentary upon Pound's "Portrait d'une Femme."

17. For the source of this phrase, see Jessica R. Feldman, "Modernism's Victorian Bric-à-Brac," 8, no. 3 : 453-70.

18. Ezra Pound and Dorothy Shakespear: Their Letters, 1909-1914, ed. Omar Pound and A. Walton Litz (New York: New Directions, 1984), 130-3. Josephine Johnson's, Florence Farr: Bernard Shaw's New Woman, (Totowa, N.J.: Rowman and Littlefield, 1975) also identifies Farr as the sitter for Pound's "portrait." There is also a small depiction of Farr in Pound's Canto XXVIII in which she appears as Loica (really Louka, from a character in Arms and the Man), a five-line depiction of her trip to Sri Lanka, and a summary epitaph.

19. A. Walton Litz, "Florence Farr: A 'Transitional Woman,'" in High and Low Moderns: Literature and Culture 1889-1939, ed. Maria DiBattista and Lucy McDiarmid (New York: Oxford University Press, 1996), 86; hereafter abbreviated "FF." See also Farr's own essays on Ibsen's heroines in this same collection.

20. Cassandra Laity, "W. B. Yeats and Florence Farr: The Influence of the 'New Woman' Actress on Yeats's Changing Images of Women," Modern Drama 28 (December 1985): 620, 635.

21. Rita Felski, The Gender of Modernity (Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1995), 16, 18.

22. Kumari Jayawardena, The White Woman's Other Burden: Western Women and South Asia During British Rule (New York: Routledge, 1995), 138.

23. Elizabeth Butler Cullingford, Gender and History in Yeats's Love Poetry (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1993), 40-1. Cullingford argues that while patriarchal religion had one male deity, a male priesthood, gender inequality, and asexual or relatively powerless female cult objects like the Virgin Mary, occult religions offered female deities, female adepts, and priestesses high status, and a sense of gender equality with a potentially sexualized and power-laden aura; thus, "the attraction of occult societies for rebellious women is obvious" .

24. James Longenbach, Stone Cottage: Pound, Yeats, and Modernism (New York: Oxford University Press, 1988), 11-4.

25. Pound and Litz, eds., Ezra Pound, 128, 343; The Letters of W. B. Yeats, ed. Allen Wade (New York: Macmillan, 1955), 274, 353-4, 373-4, 384, 394; hereafter abbreviated L.

26. See Yeats's letter of November 1902 in L, 384, 13; "FF," 87; and Richard Ellmann, Yeats: The Man and the Masks (London: Faber and Faber, 1961), 133.

27. Mark Morrisson, "Performing the Pure Voice: Elocution, Verse Recitation, and Modernist Poetry in Prewar London," 3, no. 3 : 40-1.

28. Ezra Pound, Literary Essays (London: Faber and Faber, 1954).

29. Or, conversely, Pound, the great mind, sought her, lacking someone else (Yeats). In either case she is "second always." It is also possible to "translate" this line in a way suggested by Richard Ellmann: Yeats had an affair with Farr, because Maud Gonne (the "someone else") was not available. Ellmann, Yeats, 182.

30. L, 543; note that Yeats refers to Farr by her married name although she was divorced from her husband in 1895; as for the word "queer," I shall take it to mean amusing, odd, spritely, needy.

31. Ezra Pound, ABC of Reading (New York: New Directions, 1960), 197-8. Pound also notes, on the same page, that Yeats can't sing: "he would certainly be incapable of whistling a simple melody in tune. Nevertheless before writing a lyric he is apt to 'get a chune in his head.' He is very sensitive to a limited gamut of rhythms."

32. Similarly, a provoking split in memories of Farr between her pre-Raphaelite look and her professional activities as capable performer and organizer is articulated in Yeats's final summary, which places Farr in a particular psycho-spiritual grouping in A Vision : "A certain actress [Farr] is typical [of Phase 19], for she surrounds herself with drawings by Burne-Jones in his latest period, and reveres them as they were holy pictures, while her manners are boisterous, dominating, and egotistical. They are faces of silent women, and she is not silent for a moment . . ." W. B. Yeats, A Vision (1938; New York: Macmillan, 1961), 150. The New Woman subjectivity is disparaged in these remarks and viewed as a deception. The consensus is: better silent pre-Raphaelite women than demanding modern ones who have opinions and claims. In the case of Yeats, this judgment is the more striking given Cassandra Laity's argument in her unpublished dissertation that Yeats was indebted to the New Woman in general, and to Farr in particular, in his changed depictions of warrior queens in his drama: decisive, masculine, female res of agency and force. Cassandra Laity, "From Fatal Woman to New Woman: Yeats's Changing Image of Woman in his Art and Aesthetics" (Ph.D. diss., University of Michigan, 1985).

33. This novel appeared in the same year in which Farr departed for Sri Lanka (in August) and Pound wrote his poem. Florence Farr [Emery], The Solemnization of Jacklin: Some Adventures on the Search for Reality (London: A. C. Fifield, 1912); hereafter abbreviated SJ. Dorothy wrote to Ezra, "Just read a new book by 'Florence Farr.' Such a Sargasso Sea muddle. Every body divorced several times, & in the end going back to their originals: & a young man called 'Dorus Callando' who lay among lilies all night & is Oscar [Wilde] without the bitter-sweetness." O. Pound and Litz, eds., Ezra Pound, 132.

34. Florence Farr, Modern Woman: Her Intentions (London: Frank Palmer, 1910), 7; hereafter abbreviated MW.

35. Long after this polemical analysis had been written, I found the following in a fascinating study by Kumari Jayawardena, who sketches incisive analytic pictures of European, mainly British, women who contributed in a variety of ways to South Asian life, whether as reformers, educators, or spiritual seekers. She observes that "while Pound is somewhat dismissive of Florence Farr for her dilettantism, not surprisingly, he fails to note or value her feminism, her challenge to patriarchal attitudes and her approach to education." Jayawardena's chapter is mainly devoted to Farr's end-of-career commitment to education for Hindu girls in Sri Lanka; Farr served as principal of a Ramanathan College in Jaffna for several years until just before her death in 1917, a role that became increasingly unsatisfying as her guru turned out to have rather retrograde ideas about the education of girls into wives and mothers. Jayawardena depicts Farr as "misrepresented" by the various men in her life, and uses Modern Woman briefly to trace Farr's feminist politics, although the book's racial politics are not mentioned. Jayawardena, The White Woman's Other Burden, 139, 146.

36. The Letters of Ezra Pound, 1907-1941, ed. D. D. Paige (New York: Harcourt, Brace and World, 1950), 10.

37. Pound, Literary Essays, 3.

38. On aspects of Marinetti's program, see Marjorie Perloff, The Futurist Moment: Avant-Garde, Avant Guerre, and the Language of Rupture (Chicago: The University of Chicago Press, 1986), 86-92; for gender interpretations of that program, see Peter Nicholls, Modernisms: A Literary Guide, (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1995), 84-92; Carolyn Burke, Becoming Modern: The Life of Mina Loy (New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1996), 156-7; and Janet Lyon, Manifestoes: Provocations of the Modern (Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press, 1999), 92-123; hereafter abbreviated M.

39. M, 97. This careerist spur to imagism from Marinetti is argued by A. Walton Litz and Lawrence Rainey in their essay "Ezra Pound," in The Cambridge History of Literary Criticism, vol. 7. Modernism and the New Criticism, ed. A. Walton Litz, Louis Menand, and Lawrence Rainey (New York: Cambridge University Press, 2000), 57-92, especially 68-70. I am extending their argument here to apply to "Portrait d'une Femme."

40. Litz and Rainey, "Ezra Pound," 68.

41. Filippo Tommaso Marinetti, "The Founding and Manifesto of Futurism" in Manifesto: A Century of Isms, ed. Mary Ann Caws (Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 2001), 187.

42. Again, this notion of "Victorian modernism" I am taking from Jessica Feldman. See note 16 for full citation.

43. Letter of 2 March 1917, The Selected Letters of Ezra Pound to John Quinn, 1915-1924, ed. Timothy Materer (Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press, 1991), 97. See also Ronald Bush, "Ezra Pound," in The Gender of Modernism, ed. Bonnie Kime Scott (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1990), 353-9.

9.3 407-422

[Access article in PDF]

H.D.'s Distractions:
Cinematic Stasis and Lesbian Desire

Jean Gallagher

[res]

The poet H.D.'s film-related work of the late-1920s and early-1930s constitutes an important chapter in the history of female modernist theorizing about vision. Through her essays for the film journal Close Up (which she helped to found and edit), her participation in the POOL group's production of several silent films, and her autobiographically-inflected fiction of the period, H.D. participated in and helped to modify a number of discourses within modernist visual culture. 1

Looking at the body of work H.D. produced during this period for what it might tell us about the nature of modernist visuality, I am struck by a recurring image: that of a woman (H.D. herself or her fictional protagonists) fixedly staring. re 1, from the 1930 film Borderline, suggests the level of intensity that H.D. as an actor and Kenneth Macpherson as her director invested in her stare: the image, a close-up of H.D. looking directly and intently into the camera, remains on screen for ten seconds. Other examples of the sustained, fixed stare abound in the film as well as in H.D.'s prose. In her 1926 story "Hipparchia," published the year before the founding of Close Up, the primary character is repeatedly characterized as "staring, wide-eyed," gazing fixedly, regarding, considering, contemplating, and not only looking but looking and looking. A paragraph describing Hipparchia's visual experience certainly suggests a cinema spectator fascinated and immobilized by patterns of light on a screen: "Her eyes, wide open, stared now upon the squares of neat ceiling . . . Her eyes saw light break across the ceiling, an angle of clear light. . . . She came back (staring, wide-eyed) to the ceiling across which the outer light had wandered." 2 A well-known example of H.D.'s rapt, entranced gaze appears in her 1944 description of a hallucinatory vision she experienced in 1920: "I do not budge an inch or break the sustained crystal-gazing stare at the wall before me. . . . my own head is splitting with the ache of concentration. I know that if I let go, lessen the intensity of my stare and shut my eyes or even blink my eyes, the pictures will fade out." 3

What is H.D.'s stare, and why is it such a recurring feature of her representations and self-representations? What is the possible connection of her relentlessly fixed stare to the visual culture(s) of modernism? How and why is her film-related work so invested in an aesthetic of stasis? How was H.D.'s "involve[ment] with pictures" linked to the dynamics of her domestic ménage in the late-1920s and early-1930s, which consisted of herself, her longtime female companion Bryher, and Macpherson (her bisexual male lover and Bryher's husband) and which formed the basis of the POOL film production company and the Close Up editorial board? 4 I suggest that investigating H.D.'s stare may tell us something about the contradictions and coexistences at the heart of modernist visuality and, more particularly, about the role of lesbian desire in the model of spectatorship emerging in her work.

H.D.'s abiding interest in stasis and fixity in visual experience runs counter to a significant discussion among her contemporaries about modern subjectivity and vision: that of the concept of "distraction" and its relation to mass cultural expressive forms, particularly the cinema. The nature of "distraction" was being extensively explored in the film criticism of Weimar Germany, where H.D., Bryher, and Macpherson spent time participating in Berlin's burgeoning film culture, seeing new films unavailable in England or Switzerland, and meeting directors like G. W. Pabst. 5 Many of H.D.'s German contemporaries, most notably Siegfried Kracauer and Walter Benjamin, theorized distraction as a peculiarly modern mass psychological state that developed in response to the fractures, shocks, and discontinuities of urban culture. These theorists presented "distraction" as a marked contrast to an older and allegedly outmoded model of attention: that of "contemplation" or "concentration." Concentration and contemplation were often associated in critical writing of this period with classical models of the Cartesian subject: coherent, stable, and occupying a relatively fixed position in relation to the visual object. The distracted subject, on the other hand, suggested a newly fragmented and destabilized model of subjectivity appropriate to the alienated conditions of modernity. 6

During the period that saw the establishment of the classical narrative film and large "picture palaces" in European capitals, which frequently interspersed film screenings with live vaudeville acts, the states of "distraction" and "contemplation" were often marked by class affiliation. The distracted spectator was generally associated with popular mass-cultural forms and with the urban working class, while the contemplative observer tended to be associated with the bourgeois subject engaged in a sustained relationship with the more traditional visual arts such as painting and sculpture. 7 One tension that informs H.D.'s writing for Close Up is that between embracing a popular art form generally associated with "cheap circuses, crowds, . . . illiteracy . . . and . . . a sudden collapse of jerry-built scaffolding" and the desire to construct a more hermetic film culture associated with an exclusive community of avant-garde practitioners and audience members whom she identified as "picture adept[s]." 8 H.D. attempted to resolve this tension by invoking a rapt, undistracted gaze in relation to this new and distracting art form. 9 The "picture adept" who was the subject of this contemplative gaze was a contradictory creature, one invested in an aesthetic of cinematic stasis modeled on classical statuary but also sensitive to a set of peculiar filmic "vibrations." As I will explore later in the essay, perhaps the most adept of the "picture adepts" emerging as the ideal film audience in H.D.'s work was the lesbian spectator.

H.D. clearly articulates her aesthetic of cinematic stasis in the 1927 Close Up essay "Cinema and the Classics II: Restraint." In it, H.D. asserts that the primary visual model for a successful cinematic representation is classical Greek statuary ("a pre-fifth or fifth century piece of sculpture") and involves a focus on a single image or gesture, often stripped down to a synecdochic fragment. 10 She claims that "[t]he pure classic does not depend for effect . . . on a whole, part has always been important, chiselling and cutting, shaping and revising. A laurel grove rises in one branch set against a plain room wall. . . . perhaps some little unexpected effect of a bare arm lifted might bring back . . . all of antiquity " ("CCR," 111, 114). H.D.'s stage directions for her translation of Euripedes's Ion, published in 1937 but composed in the late teens and the early 1930s, indicate a similar kind of attachment to stasis in dramatic performance: "Gesture may be simple, direct copy of marble arm and bared limb of pentellic frieze. . . . He may stand, in hieratic posture, scarcely moving, uttering frigid syllables like a marble statue." 11

H.D.'s focus on the single gesture and the static, statue-like image arises not only from her early training in imagism and a Paterian aesthetics that placed a high value on artistic "restraint" and the hieratic qualities of Greek statuary, but it also reflects two important developments in the theory and practice of European silent film. 12 The first was the Weimar melodrama, which according to Patrice Petro, frequently employed fixed tableaux and "studied compositions at moments of narrative crises" that tended to break "with narrative suspense in favor of an attention to composition and atmosphere." 13 The second development, emerging in French film criticism in the years immediately following World War I, shifted the focus from the action or narrative line of a film to the disruptive power of the single cinematic image, which French writers termed photogénie. 14 The "photogenic" moment was one in which the single image, though part of a narrative trajectory, entered the foreground of spectatorial attention and, at the same time, gestured toward an enduring, Platonic "reality" beyond the surface image. For film critics such as Emile Vuillermoz writing in the late teens, the photogenic power of the single cinematic image was a remarkably static one: the cinema "cuts out of space and fixes in time inimitable images; [it] seizes in flight and immortalizes the fleeting moment when nature possesses genius" (qtd. in FF, 108). Moreover, for French theorists of photogénie, this fixity extended beyond the cinematic image to include the spectator: in the photogenic conception of film, "the camera functioned as a mediator between the spectator and a certain reality or 'world' and as an instrument of revelation. . . . it positioned the spectator before that mediated reality . . . in a state of rapt attention or absorption" (FF, 107). The notion of film as an "instrument of revelation" is one that H.D. certainly supported; she often wrote of the cinema's ability to convey "something behind something," suggesting an unchanging Platonic essence beneath or beyond the surface of the cinematic image. 15 This conception of film as a static, revelatory medium is very similar to Walter Pater's assumptions about the nature of Greek statues, which as Eileen Gregory has shown, were influential in the development of H.D.'s poetics. For Pater, classical statues "do not so much exemplify sublimity and nobility of form as they convey revelations of the invisible and eternal" (HH, 41).

Just as the concept of photogénie establishes a defamiliarizing stasis in both image and spectator, H.D.'s valorization of the single, statue-like image within the film also constructs a fixed spectatorial gaze. When H.D. describes her experience of what she perceives as an excess of movement on the screen, her anxiety about its effect on the coherence of the seeing subject is clear: "Ben Hur drove his chariot with decorum and with fervour but . . . when I would begin to criticize I am lost myself in a tangle of exciting detail, am myself so startled and amazed by certain swiftness, certain effects of inevitable precise mass movement . . . that I lose my own clue, become sated and lost and tired" ("CCR," 111). In contrast to the "tangle of exciting detail" in the more dynamic film image that causes the spectator to get "lost," H.D.'s aesthetic agenda for the cinema involves, as she says, the search for the "one gesture (not too frigid and not too stagily static)" (ibid.). Her ideal film should, however, be "frigid" and "stagily static" enough to ensure the stability of the spectator's subjectivity:

The true classic is not a thing of built up walls . . . and pasteboard perspective. Streets and by-ways should be on one plane, we should be somewhere, not all over the place. We should be somewhere with our minds, lines should radiate as toward a centre not out and away from the central point of interest. . . . We should be somewhere, our getting on somewhere else will come in due course. ["CCR," 110-11]

H.D.'s repeated, emphatic plea that "we should be somewhere" suggests an anxiety about visual excess—not only an excess of movement or objects within the visual field, but also an excess of motion in the spectator's visual attention, generated by an overly-complex set. H.D.'s aesthetic of viewing here seeks to fix the eye's wandering glances within a static, pared-down visual field.

H.D.'s search for a simplified visual field reflects a development in late-nineteenth-century psychology that defined attention as the ability and need to isolate some aspects of the perceptual field and to exclude others in order to organize sensory input and to ensure the stability of subjectivity. Jonathan Crary suggests that this concept of attention is central to the very notion of individual subjectivity in Western modernity, which "has demanded that individuals define and shape themselves in terms of a capacity for 'paying attention,' that is for disengagement from a broader field of attraction . . . for the sake of isolating or focusing on a reduced number of stimuli." 16 Similarly, in her fiction, H.D. defines art in terms of a delimiting focus: "The things are there all the time, but art [is] . . . a focus, a sense of proportion like turning the little wheel of an opera glass, getting a great mass of inchoate colour and form into focus, focussing on one small aspect of life though really it is only a tiny circle, a tiny circle." 17

The same contemplative, concentrated, focused attention that H.D. invokes to suggest the possibility of a stable, undistracted relationship to the usually distracting cinematic image was itself understood during the early-twentieth century as closely related to the breakdown of stable vision, subjectivity, and identity. In a 1927 Close Up editorial, Kenneth Macpherson describes an entranced state of excessive visual fixation that he claims is the lamentable result of viewing inferior (most likely popular) films: "when the film is not good enough to keep the brain working, the public sinks into a kind of hypnotic daze. The screen, with its changing forms becomes something in the nature of a crystal, and the public in the nature of a crystal gazer. Mind in some way neatly obliterates itself." 18 The state that Macpherson describes, one in which the absorbed, rapt gaze contributes to an obliteration or destabilizing of vision and subjectivity, resonates with Crary's notion of "suspension" as a salient quality of modern attention. Crary, drawing on the work of late-nineteenth-century psychologists, defines attentive suspension as "a looking or listening so rapt that it is an exemption from ordinary conditions, that it becomes a suspended temporality, a hovering out of time" (SP, 9). This is a state that blurs the distinction between concentration and the far more unpredictable and unmanageable states of reverie, trance, or dissociation. This fixated attention, verging on more trance-like states, involves both an intensification of perception and, as a result of this intensification, "a cancellation or an interruption . . . a disturbance, even a negation of perception itself" (SP, 10). Others during the first half of the twentieth century commented on this phenomenon, in which the intense stare actually limits and even disables perception. For example, Aldous Huxley noted that if through dependence on "artificial lenses or bad habits," the gaze grows too fixed and the eye loses its mobility, and thereby its ability to scan objects, "the sensory apparatus undergoes distortion and vision degenerates. . . . In his greedy anxiety to achieve his end, which is to the greatest possible amount of good seeing in the shortest possible time, the starer neglects the only means whereby this can be achieved." 19

The "crystal-gazer" with "bad habits" whose fixed stare borders on trance or cognitive dissociation makes frequent appearances in H.D.'s prose fiction of the 1920s. One example, from the novel Asphodel, demonstrates the kind of suspended attention that Crary describes: "Hermione stared at the wall. . . . Her eyes seemed to see nothing. Were open, staring like glass eyes, saw nothing, grey glass eyes, but her eyelids seemed pricked with luminous light, seemed to burn, to glow with some light within—eyes and they see not—her glass grey eyes didn't see anything, would never see anything" (A, 201).

In the fictional work that features this kind of hallucinatory suspended attention, the cause of this perceptual state is often related to a variety of lesbian desires and encounters. (HER)mione, Asphodel, and "Hipparchia" all represent lesbian relationships resembling those in H.D.'s own life (primarily her early relationship with Frances Gregg and her later relationship with Bryher). The texts describe these relationships not only in terms of vision, but also in terms of intense, rapt staring and shared hallucination and trance—states very similar to the suspended attention that marks Macpherson's "crystal-gazing" moviegoer. For example, in Asphodel, Hermione travels to France with her female lover, Fayne Rabb, and visits Rouen, the city where Joan of Arc was tried and executed. Hermione describes Joan in terms that echo late-nineteenth-century sexologists' definitions of the sexual invert—"a girl who was a boy"—and closely associates Joan's religious visions with Hermione's and Fayne's habit of "seeing things . . . having 'visions,' seeing things like she did and like Fayne Rabb." 20 In fictional episodes that parallel H.D.'s first meeting with Bryher, the Bryher-like characters are repeatedly represented as intense starers equipped with "eyes that looked and looked" (A, 178; "H," 92, 94). Her protagonists respond not only by participating in a mutual, mirroring gaze ("staring back into eyes that stared and stared" [A, 175]; "regarding a pair of beryl eyes that looked and looked" ["H," 92]) but also by hallucination: "Don't let me get hysterical for she makes me see things" (A, 175, 180). I wish to suggest that it is precisely this kind of contradictory, suspended attention—rapt, fixated, and absorbed as well as destabilized and ungrounded—that emerges as a model for spectatorial subjectivity in H.D.'s film work, and it is one that is repeatedly associated with the literally entrancing effects of lesbian desire throughout H.D.'s oeuvre.

In her film writing, H.D. observes, admires, and attempts to represent and elicit such a state of entranced, suspended attention in her description of the photogenic, static aspects of Alexandra Khokhlova's performance in Lev Kuleshov's 1926 film By the Law. She writes:

The gestures of this woman are angular, bird-like, claw-like, skeleton-like and hideous. . . . Her gestures are magnificent. If this is Russian, then I am Russian. . . . this woman is a sort of bleak young sorceress, vibrant, febrile, neurotic . . . almost cataleptic. She has one authentic mad scene: her mind breaks after hours of watching the prisoner with the gun placed edge-wise like some iron bar-across numbed and frozen knees. . . . Her mind is on the raw edge of breaking. . . . Her mind, her soul, her body, her spirit, her being, all vibrate . . . almost audibly. 21

As with the single images and pared-down stage sets that H.D. posits as the cinematic ideal, her admiration of this film is based on Khokhlova's static, "numbed and frozen" qualities—a stasis that borders, as she says, on catalepsis, and yet is also characterized by intense "vibration." As suggested in res 2 and 3, Khokhlova conveys this psychological condition through eyeball-exposing, rapt staring—images of which, like the image of H.D. staring into the camera in Borderline, remain on the screen for at least ten seconds. I would suggest that H.D. is not only admiring an actress' ability to represent the seemingly contradictory state of vibrant catalepsis; her film-related work also posits a model of spectatorial response that encompasses both qualities. H.D. offers herself as a model of just such a spectator when she explicitly identifies with Khokhlova's image ("if this is Russian, then I am Russian") and announces that "I, personally, am attuned to certain vibration" emanating from the screen, which, she claims, Kuleshov "uses . . . almost as a psychic medium" ("E," 127).

H.D.'s identification with Khokhlova's simultaneously vibrant and cataleptic screen image might be read not only as a model for spectatorial response, but even more specifically as a set of directions for viewing her own screen image. When H.D. saw By the Law in 1928, she had already appeared in Wing Beat and would act in two more POOL films (Foothills and Borderline) within the next two years. Images of H.D. in Borderline (. 1, 4, 5, and 6) might easily be described with the same language she uses to describe Khokhlova: "angular, bird-like, claw-like, skeleton-like and hideous"; "vibrant, febrile, neurotic"; "almost cataleptic"; demonstrating "an agony of neurotic almost epileptic strength"; "a great locust, all legs, hardly any flesh" ("E," 128, 129).

H.D.'s focus on both the simultaneously static and vibrant aspects of Khokhlova's screen image also bears a striking resemblance to the language of a full-page advertisement in Close Up for the POOL group's 1927 film Wing Beat: "Telepathy and attraction, the reaching out, the very edge of dimensions in dimensions, the chemistry of actual attraction, of will shivering and quivering on a frail, too-high, too inaccessible brink. WING BEAT shakes and trembles from its first moment. . . . Of minds and spirits, not of persons." 22 Like H.D.'s description of Khokhlova, the rhapsodic language of the ad emphasizes both stasis and vibration. There is a dearth of active verbs and complete sentences, which are replaced mostly by a series of apposite nouns or noun phrases and gerunds. The verbs that are here (shivering, quivering, shakes, trembles) signal the most minute of movements, almost not movement at all, but rather something in between stasis and movement, perceived haptically or psychically, rather than visually. [Begin Page 416]

H.D. uses a similar vocabulary of stasis and vibration in an unpublished essay on the film Wing Beat:

So the world beats and pulses in this modest four reel film. . . . But it is a world of reality, of a simple setting, a lyric setting and to all intents and purposes, no action. The action . . . is the action of subtle "stills," an action of thought etched in fine distinguished line on the fine distinguished features of Mr. Macpherson and of H.D., the writer, poet-critic who has taken part in the film. . . . This is the world lived by the nervous, post-war thinker, artist, intellectual; nerve-wrought, hysterical . . . but vibrant, pulsing with life and with rarefied emotion. 23

In H.D.'s description of her own screen image, the only "action" is that of emotionally rarefied "stills," reminiscent of the significance-laden fixed tableaux of expressionist film melodramas. These nerve-wrought, hysterical, vibrant, pulsing "stills" also recall the nervous condition found in Walter Pater's description of the daughters of Herodias, oracular priestesses who, according to Eileen Gregory, served H.D. as models for the "visionary female artist": "Nervous, electric, faint always with some inexplicable faintness, these people seem to be subject to exceptional conditions, to feel powers at work in the common air unfelt by others" (qtd. in HH, 81).

The "film still" that constitutes the focus of female spectatorial identification here also makes an appearance in later feminist film theory's depiction of the gendered dichotomy of stasis and movement that adheres to the classical narrative film. Teresa DeLauretis describes this dichotomy when she claims that, "the female spectator is classically split between" on the one hand, identification with "the image on the screen, perceived as spatially static, fixed," and feminine, and on the other hand, "identification with the camera, apprehended as temporal, active," and masculine. 24 H.D.'s description of the experience of working under Macpherson's direction in the making of Borderline clearly reflects this dichotomy, as Macpherson appears engaged in frantic directorial activity, arranging and posing his rather lumpish actors, including H.D. herself:

He directs an elaborate series of overhead and side and ground lights, he writes a script which he meticulously illustrates with a series of some 1,000 pen sketches, he chooses his troop of players, he poses them, he all but acts for them, he directs from behind the camera while all the time he himself is concerned with the elaborate one-man mechanism of various stops, different focuses, indeterminate "pans" up and down, and the very tricky job of the sheer turning. 25

It is clear that H.D.'s position as a film spectator and critic is heavily influenced by her experience as a film actor and by her (idealized) perceptions of her own screen image. It is tempting to read her act of looking at the vibrant/cataleptic woman on the screen as a form of extended, contemplative self-regard. The image of her looking at her own and other female images looking back at her via the camera would seem the apotheosis of Mary Ann Doane's description of the female spectator of classical Hollywood film, for whom "there is a certain overpresence of the image—she is the image" and whose "desire can be described only in terms of a kind of narcissism." 26 Understood in this way, H.D.'s rapt, absorbed gaze is at its most intensely absorbed when she is looking at her own screen image looking back at herself.

Such a narcissistic model of female spectatorship might present particular anxiety for a lesbian spectator, particularly one who, like H.D., was familiar with the work of sexologists like her and Bryher's friend Havelock Ellis, an early proponent of the association of the myth of Narcissus with autoeroticism and homosexuality. 27 As Carolyn Allen has observed, the discourses of modern sexology "pathologize[d] the same-sex erotic dynamic as extreme self-enclosure under the rubric of narcissism." H.D.'s film-related writing evidences a dismayed awareness of the pejorative aspects of the "narcissist" construction of lesbian erotics, but it also offers a potentially redemptive revision of "narcissism" for a lesbian aesthetics of cinematic relations. 28

H.D.'s descriptions of her own domestic and sexual ménage with Bryher and Macpherson, particularly her relationship to Bryher within the ménage, evidence her concerns about the potentially stultifying, petrifying effects of both cinematic spectatorship and lesbian erotics. 29 In a 1928 letter, she described her relationship with Bryher and Macpherson as "very static and 'classic,'" exactly the terms she uses to describe her ideal film aesthetic. 30 However, this "static and classic" relation, especially with Bryher, is also marked by unease, visible in a set of metaphors describing the lesbian body as a machine, in particular a photographic machine. In the 1928 story "Narthex," which offers a fictional account of a trip H.D., Bryher, and Macpherson took to Venice around the time of Bryher's and Macpherson's marriage, H.D.'s protagonist and fictional alter ego Raymonde describes her female lover Gareth as a "steel blue recorder" and complains to her male lover Daniel that "'Gareth is purely mechanical in all her reaction. . . . she sees me rather than perceives me. . . . She watches me . . . watching. She doesn't want to watch me absorbing. She wants to watch me watching.'" 31 Gareth in this formulation is a film camera, engaged in a mechanical "seeing" rather than a more engaged "perceiving." Moreover, Raymonde suggests that Gareth's desire seeks to elicit a similar kind of mechanical vision—"watching" rather than "absorbing"—in Raymonde, portraying the two women as a pair of film cameras, mutually engaged in mechanical, inhuman vision. 32

In the pamphlet she wrote to accompany Borderline, H.D. also refers to Macpherson as a "machine man" whose body is coextensive with the camera he uses to shoot the film in which she and Bryher appear: "Kenneth Macpherson, at work, is a hard-boiled mechanic, as if he himself were all camera." 33 However, this conflation of machine and male lover/film director appears as a productive hybridization of body and machine and seems to generate none of the dyslogistic associations of the mechanized Gareth, who is several times called a "robot" in H.D.'s 1928 fiction The Usual Star. 34 The concern about mechanistic vision, associated here particularly with lesbian relations, reflects an anxiety that, according to Louis Commoli, accompanied the rise of photography: "the human eye loses its immemorial privilege; the mechanical eye of the photographic machine now sees in its place, and in certain aspects with more sureness. The photograph stands as the triumph and grave of the eye." 35 The image of the lesbian couple as a matched pair of film cameras suggests a completely mechanized narcissistic gaze, one in which the lesbian body itself serves as the "triumph and grave of the eye."

H.D.'s linking of the lesbian body to the narcissistic machinery of the camera and robot echoes her ambivalence about the rise of sound in cinema. Puzzling over her disappointment in a sound film starring the Spanish singer Raquel Meller, she claimed that "[t]he screen image, a mask, a sort of doll or marionette was somehow mechanized and robbed of the thing behind the thing that has grown to matter so much to the picture adept. A doll . . . became a sort of robot" ("CCM,"115). Although she is dealing here with a set of metaphors for the screen image quite different from classical statuary, the doll, like the marble statue, still retains a potentially revelatory quality, capable of granting to the "picture adept" access to "the thing behind the thing," the Platonic eidos lingering behind the photogénie of the silent film image. The singing "robot," however, seems to close off this access, reducing the cinematic experience to a mere surface image. No depth, no absorption, no perception: only a superficial engagement with the readily reproducible mechanical entity and mechanically-generated image. Returning to Raymonde's complaint that "[s]he wants to watch me watching" as a dystopic mechanization of the dynamic of female lovers "staring back into eyes that stared and stared," we can read in H.D.'s work an anxiety about the specter of lesbian erotics as an endless mechanical mise en abîme, reminiscent of the female spectator locked in a "narcissistic" engagement with the female screen image looking back at her.

H.D. reported with pleasure her engagement with film technology; she noted in her response to a 1929 Little Review questionnaire, "I myself have learned to use the small projector" and "can do a little work on the small camera." 36 However, there lingers in her work a profound apprehension about the mechanical aspects of cinema—not only its "appliances" and "intricate machinery," but the mechanical generation and reproducibility of its images ("CCM,"114). This apprehension is linked in her writing to the pejorative sexological claims of narcissism that tend to gather around the lesbian body. H.D.'s emphasis on contemplative, even worshipful absorption in the film image, her suspicion of the cinematic "robot," and her valorization of the photogenic film image's ability to offer the "picture adept" access to the hermetic "thing behind the thing," participated in what Walter Benjamin perceived as a mistaken effort of film critics in the late 1920s to establish the "ritual" or "cult value" of the cinematic image, despite the fact that the mechanically-reproduced film image was detached from the "aura" of the "authentic," mechanically-unreproducible art work. 37

However, H.D.'s attempt to establish the cult value of the film image involved another agenda as well: rescuing lesbian desire from the damaging associations of narcissism, troped here not so much as self-reflection but rather as mechanical reproducibility. One method by which H.D. attempts to address and resolve her apprehension about the "robotic" aspects of lesbian desire involves her vibrant-cataleptic mode of film performance and reception. This method is closely connected to her recurrent valorization of the classical statue as the model not only for the cinematic image but for lesbian erotics. By describing lesbian desire in terms not only of the petrifying, narcissistic vision-machine or robot but rather in terms of the simultaneously static and vibrant classical statuary which forms the basis for her cinema aesthetic, she attempts to represent what Allen has described as a sexual "relation of identity layered with res of alterity," an erotics based on a shifting balance of identity and difference. 38

This kind of erotics is evidenced in the novel (HER)mione, composed in the late 1920s, when the protagonist Hermione (or Her), envisioning herself as a statue, conflates her own name both with the feminine object pronoun and her female lover: "Keep a marble self for a marble self, Her for Her, Her for Fayne exactly." 39 Several readers have observed that H.D. often associates classical statuary with lesbian sexuality, particularly lesbian sexuality understood as both homoerotic and autoerotic. 40 The lesbian statuary that emerges here is not purely static, but also the animated, vibrant statuary of H.D.'s "restrained" cinematic ideal. An erotic encounter between Hermione and Fayne is described in terms of a cinematic experience, complete with curtains parting to reveal a screen close-up: "Her bent forward, face bent toward Her. A face bends toward me and a curtain opens. There is swish and swirl as of heavy parting curtains. . . . Curtains part as I look into the eyes of Fayne Rabb. 'And I—I'll make you breathe, my breathless statue.' 'Statue? You—you are the statue.'" 41

With its heavy-breathing (or at least the promise of heavy-breathing) sexual rapport between the closely-identified female spectator and the female image, both of whom are characterized as "statues" animated by their cinematic/sexual encounter, this passage suggests the sort of "picture adept" H.D. is attempting to model in her film writing. The female spectator thereby engages autoerotically and homoerotically with a female screen image that is both self and other, static and animated, or, like Khokhlova's and H.D.'s own screen image, cataleptic and vibrant. H.D.'s simultaneously contemplative and distracted or "suspended" stare at the female screen image that is both self and other anticipates Roland Barthes's claim that "Photography is the advent of myself as other" and indicates her contribution to modernist women's theorizing of lesbian desire in the age of mechanical reproduction. 42

 


Jean Gallagher is Associate Professor of English at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, New York. She is the author of The World Wars Through the Female Gaze (Southern Illinois University Press, 1998) and is currently working on a study of women's literary modernism and visual culture.

Notes

1. See Laura Marcus, "The Contribution of H.D.: Introduction," in Close Up 1927 -1933: Cinema and Modernism, ed. James Donald, Anne Friedberg, and Laura Marcus (Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1998); hereafter abbreviated CU. See also Anne Friedberg's several works: "Approaching Borderline" in H.D.: Woman and Poet, ed. Michael King (Orono, Maine: National Poetry Foundation, 1986); "Close Up: Writing About Cinema 1927-1933" (Ph.D. diss., New York University, 1983); "Introduction: Reading Close Up, 1927-1933" in CU; and "On H.D., Woman, History, Recognition," Wide Angle 5, no. 2 : 26-31.

2. H.D., "Hipparchia," in Palimpsest (1926; Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press, 1968), 37, 39; hereafter abbreviated "H."

3. H.D., "Writing on the Wall," in Tribute to Freud (Boston: D. R. Godine, 1974), 47, 49. Many of H.D.'s readers have commented on this episode. See, for example, Adelaide Morris's essay that identifies H.D.'s 1920 hallucination as one "which marked and measured the rest of her life." "The Concept of Projection: H.D.'s Visionary Powers,"in Signets: Reading H.D., ed. Susan Stanford Friedman and Rachel Blau DuPlessis (Madison: University of Wisconsin Press, 1990), 373.

4. In addition to her film acting, film criticism, and film-editing work, H.D. spent time not only going to movie houses but projecting films at home. In a 1929 Little Review questionnaire, she described this array of activities, claiming "I am involved with pictures." H.D., "Confession," Little Review 12 : 38. For information on the POOL Group, see Friedberg, "Approaching Borderline" and Marcus, "The Contribution of H.D.: Introduction." For discussions of the dynamics of the H.D.-Bryher-Macpherson mènage, see Susan Stanford Friedman, Penelope's Web: Gender, Modernity, H.D.'s Fiction (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1990), 230-1; hereafter abbreviated PW. See also Jean Walton, "White Neurotics, Black Primitives, and the Queer Matrix of Borderline," in Out Takes: Essays on Queer Theory and Film, ed. Ellis Hanson (Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press, 1999), 246-52 and Barbara Guest, Herself Defined: The Poet H.D. and Her World (New York: Doubleday, 1984), 179-206.

5. See Guest, Herself Defined, 191-5.

6. See Siegfried Kracauer, The Mass Ornament: Weimar Essays, ed. and trans. Thomas Y. Levin (Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1995); Walter Benjamin, Illuminations, trans. Harry Zohn (New York: Schoken, 1969), 241-3; Patrice Petro, Joyless Streets: Women and Melodramatic Representation in Weimar Germany (Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1989), 52-9; and Tim Armstrong, Modernism, Technology, and the Body: A Cultural Study (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1998), 214-9.

7. See Benjamin, Illuminations, 241.

8. H.D., "Cinema and the Classics I: Beauty," in CU, 105 and "Cinema and the Classics III: The Mask and the Movietone," in CU, 115; hereafter abbreviated "CCM."

9. Other Close Up contributors also explicitly examined the contemplative possibilities of film and the importance of stillness in the spectator. Dorothy Richardson, for example, claimed that film rendered the spectator "the motionless, observing center" and thereby allowed "the reduction, or elevation of the observer to the condition that is essential to perfect contemplation." "Continuous Performance: Narcissus," in CU, 202-3.

10. H.D., "Cinema and the Classics II: Restraint," in CU, 110; hereafter abbreviated "CCR."

11. H.D., Ion (1937; Redding Ridge, Conn.: Black Swan, 1986), 17; for more on the history behind the composition of Ion, see PW, 363.

12. On Walter Pater's theory of ascesis and its influence on H.D.'s poetics, see Eileen Gregory, H.D. and Hellenism: Classic Lines (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1997), 85-90; hereafter abbreviated HH. On Pater's conception of Greek statuary, see HH, 41.

13. Petro, Joyless Streets, 32. Petro's observations on the features of Weimar melodrama draw on Peter Brooks's The Melodramatic Imagination. Brooks has observed that "there tends throughout melodramas, and most especially at the end of scenes and acts, to be a resolution of meaning in tableau, where the characters' attitudes and gestures, compositionally arranged and frozen for a moment, give, like an illustrative painting, a visual summary of the emotional situation." The Melodramatic Imagination: Balzac, Henry James, Melodrama, and the Mode of Excess (New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press, 1976), 48.

14. Richard Abel, French Film Theory and Criticism, 1907-1939: A History/Anthology. Vol. I: 1907-1929 (Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1988), 107; hereafter abbreviated FF.

15. H.D., "Joan of Arc," in CU, 133.

16. Jonathan Crary, Suspensions of Perception: Attention, Spectacle and Modern Culture (Cambridge, Mass.: MIT Press, 1998), 1; hereafter abbreviated SP.

17. H.D., Asphodel, ed. Robert Spoo (Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press, 1992), 175-6; hereafter abbreviated A.

18. Kenneth Machpherson, "As Is," Close Up 1, no. 4 :14.

19. Quoted in Paul Virilio, The Vision Machine (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1994), 2.

20. On sexological constructions of the "invert" see John Addington Symonds, A Problem in Modern Ethics: Being an Inquiry into the Phenomenon of Sexual Inversion (1896; New York: Benjamin Blom, 1971); Havelock Ellis, "Sexual Inversion," in Studies in the Psychology of Sex, Vol. I (1897; New York: Random House, 1942), 1-2; George Chauncey, "From Sexual Inversion to Homosexuality: Medicine and the Changing Conceptualization of Female Deviance," Salmagundi 58-9 (fall 1982-winter 1983): 116; Chesire Calhoun, "The Gender Closet: Lesbian Disappearance Under the Sign 'Women,'" in Lesbian Subjects, ed. Martha Vicinus (Bloomington: Illinois University Press, 1996), 223-4; Lillian Faderman, Surpassing the Love of Men: Romantic Friendship and Love between Women from the Renaissance to the Present (New York: William Morrow, 1981), 243; and Martha Vicinus, "They Wonder to Which Sex I Belong: The Historical Roots of the Modern Lesbian Identity," Feminist Studies 18, no. 3 : 480-1. For a discussion of Havelock Ellis's meeting with Bryher to discuss the theory of inversion, see Diana Collecott, H.D. and Sapphic Modernism (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1999), 186-9.

21. H.D. refers to the film as Expiation, the English translation of its German title, S(integral)hne. She does not refer to Khokhlova by name but rather as Edith, the name of the character Khokhlova portrays in the film. H.D., "Expiation," in CU, 126-7; hereafter abbreviated "E."

22. Advertisement for Wing Beat, Close Up 1, no. 1 .

23. H.D. Papers, Beinecke Library, Yale University.

24. Quoted in Kaja Silverman, The Threshold of the Visible World (New York: Routledge, 1996), 35.

25. "Borderline," in The Gender of Modernism: A Critical Anthology, ed. Bonnie Kime Scott (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1990).

26. Mary Ann Doane, Femmes Fatales: Feminism, Film Theory, Psychoanalysis (New York: Routledge, 1991), 22.

27. On Ellis and theories of narcissism, see Steven Bruhm, Reflecting Narcissus: A Queer Aesthetic (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 2001), 4, 129. On Bryher's and H.D.'s friendship with Ellis, see Collecott, H.D. and Sapphic Modernism, 186-91.

28. Allen numbers among several critics and theorists such as Teresa DeLauretis, Michael Warner, Ellis Hanson, and Steven Bruhm, who have recently articulated theoretical positions that attempt to recuperate "narcissism" as a "tool of resistance rather than a delimiting foundation of identity and diagnosis." See Bruhm, Reflecting Narcissus, 6 and Carolyn Allen, "The Erotics of Nora's Narrative in Djuna Barnes's Nightwood," Signs 19, no. 1 : 189.

29. Eileen Gregory has identified in H.D.'s poetry a recognition of "the threat of fixity" and "the danger of petrification" (HH, 90). Anne Friedberg also describes H.D.'s relation to the cinematic apparatus in terms of fixity: "transfixed as spectator-subject in front of the screen . . . and fixed as image on the screen." "On H.D.," 31.

30. Quoted in Diana Collecott, "Images at the Crossroads: The 'H.D. Scrapbook,'" in H.D.: Woman and Poet, ed. King, 355.

31. H.D., "Narthex," in The Second American Caravan, ed. Alfred Kreymborg, Luis Mumford, and Paul Rosenfeld (New York: Macauley, 1928), 230, 273; ellipses in original.

32. Tim Armstrong observes that in her 1927 poem, "If I am a needle on a disk," published in Transition, Bryher "pictures the writer as a transcription device" where "the self is fragile, subsumed to technology." Modernism, Technology, 116. See Bryher, "Three Poems," in In Transition: A Paris Anthology, ed. Noel Riley Fitch (New York: Doubleday, 1990), 66-7.

33. H.D., "Borderline," 114.

34. H.D., The Usual Star (Dijon: Darantiére, 1934), 28, 38.

35. Quoted in Martin Jay, Downcast Eyes: The Denigration of Vision in Twentieth-Century French Thought (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1993), 149.

36. H.D., "Confession," 38.

37. Benjamin, Illuminations, 226-30. One example of H.D.'s reading of the cinema as a form of religious ritual is in "Restraint": "Here is our medium . . . here is the thing that the Elusinians [sic] would have been glad of; a subtle device for portraying of the miraculous. Miracles and godhead are not out of place, are not awkward on the screen" ("CCR," 112).

38. Allen, "The Erotics of Nora's Narrative," 189-90.

39. H.D., (HER)mione (New York: New Directions, 1981), 176. For more on the publication history of the novel, see PW, 362.

40. See HH, 95; Collecott, "Images," 349, 352; and Cassandra Laity, "Lesbian Romanticism: H.D.'s Representations of Frances Gregg and Bryher," introduction to Paint it Today, by H.D. (New York: New York University Press, 1992), xxviii-ix. Gregory traces this understanding of the classical statue to Pater, for whom classical marble statuary represents not only "a transcendent asexuality" but also "comes to be associated with bisexuality—with the re of the hermaphrodite or androgyne, representing an original unity of being" (qtd. in HH, 93).

41. H.D., (HER)mione, 163.

42. Roland Barthes, Camera Lucida: Reflections on Photography, trans. Richard Howard (New York: Farrar, Straus, Giroux, 1981), 12.

9.3 463-489

[Access article in PDF]

Modernist Polemic:
Ezra Pound v. "the perverters of language"

Matthew Hofer

[res]

8. We set Humour at Humour's throat.
Stir up Civil War among peaceful apes.
9. We only want Humour if it has fought like Tragedy.
10. We only want Tragedy if it can clench its side-
muscles like hands on its belly, and bring to
the surface a laugh like a bomb.

—"Vorticist Manifesto" 1

Predication and Attribution, or Publication as Public Action

"I take it in retrospect that my tendency to action had effects," Ezra Pound asserted in his radio broadcast on the vorticist journal BLAST, "and that the vast majority of the small minority into contact with which I came, was uneasy, disturbed, horrified in fact: for that sign of action was also some sort of a harbinger." 2 His repeated reference to action, and to the effects of an active presence in literary language, was anything but incidental. The avant-garde satires that he had published in June 1914 were indeed a harbinger of increasingly polemical poems, and his Hell Cantos (numbers 14 and 15), drafted in the spring and summer of 1922, inaugurated an extreme style of poetic invective in which words were crafted as weapons and images designed to wound. Taken together in their own historical moment, the Hell Cantos represent the highest stage of development in Pound's discursive battle with modernity's monopolists following his retreat from London in January 1921. 3 As he refined his efforts to express his "impersonal indignation" at those forces that had effectively exiled him—and that he felt were obstructing, obfuscating, and obscuring what was best in postwar culture and society—the polemical poetic that had begun its evolution with BLAST ultimately came to test the limits of aesthetic representation. 4 These poems, through their almost visual and certainly visceral effects, are the first to conform fully to the etymology of polemic's Greek root, polemos, as "war." And yet Pound did not wage war (only) on the now-familiar political and economic targets, nor had his mode of assault yet been marred by fascistic or anti-Semitic rhetoric. Rather, he directed his counterstrike against

those who had lied for hire;
the perverts, the perverters of language,
      the perverts, who have set money lust
Before the pleasures of the senses. . . . 5

My analysis of Pound's polemic tracks a proliferation of modes of linguistic assault and means of attributing enemies that begins with BLAST and culminates in A Draft of XVI. Cantos toward a Poem of Some Length (and that later devolves into the diatribes of Jefferson and/or Mussolini and the incendiary broadcasts from Radio Rome). By paying particular attention first to the ways in which verbal invective works, and then to the process by which enemies were singled out for various kinds of assaults, we can discover much about the trajectory of Pound's career in London, Paris, and Rapallo. That is to say, while an attraction to polemic need not lead indelibly to racial intolerance, economic determinism, or political extremism, in this case it demonstrably encouraged the last at the very least. 6 It also contributed to some less predictable developments. Some of the surprises that attend Pound's sense of what constitutes an "enemy" bear on received versions of literary and cultural histories alike. The isolation of G. K. Chesterton as the model for the unserious artist was the first of a series of oppositions to persons, institutions, and ideals by which Pound defined himself throughout his life. Chesterton was Pound's first public enemy in the field of cultural production. His eventual replacement in that role by T. S. Eliot—in the guise of "Possum Episcopus"—recommends a closer look at perhaps the most celebrated collaboration between two poets in the twentieth century, that involving the editing and marketing of The Waste Land. The uncelebrated Hell Cantos, in which The Waste Land is parodied and Eliot appears not once but twice, are therefore a singularly important resource for the discovery of what those oppositions were and what they were not. The evolution of these oppositions parallels and informs Pound's program for poetry during the crucial period of 1914-22, and it is, by implication, a vital part of the story of high modernism.

As a literary form, polemic sometimes resembles the satirical and sometimes the obscene, but it is different from both and more potent than either. These differences can, however, at times, be subtle. For example, a relatively fluid continuum does exist between Pound's sense of his own avant-garde "satire," which may be defined as both a spirit and an art, and his purer polemic, which intensifies satire's oppositional spirit even as it breaks with a number of the formal characteristics of its art. Indeed, Pound himself continued to refer to all of his oppositional poetry as satiric long after his poems quit conforming to any conventional generic or historical understanding of postclassical satire. 7 In the so-called satirical poems published in BLAST, he was already straining against the limits of those written in the vein of the great eighteenth-century British satirists. He acknowledged that the modern impulse toward concreteness, specificity, and direct presentation was at odds with this British tradition, claiming "that Hubridas, Pope, even Crabbe all take us to a dated world, to a past state of England." 8 He further realized that the "unexpectedness of even a very good joke is bound to wear off on the fifth or sixth reading," and concluded that satiric wit "wears off in just the measure that it is 'abstract,' general statement or comment, and not particular presentation" (ABCR, 165). His disparagement of the inefficacy and transience of generality prevented the majority of his own satires (with a few notable exceptions, such as "Hugh Selwyn Mauberley" and "Homage to Sextus Propertius") from being truly satirical.

The BLAST poems, Pound felt, compensated for the shortcomings of traditional English-language satire by being as affective and enduring as they were precise. To this end, he contended that with them it had become a crucial "part of his position . . . that one should name names in satire." 9 But Pound resolutely denied that those indictments conveyed any animosity. His later tendency to express impersonal indignation as personal animosity was limited not only in the 1910s but also through the 1920s (and even the better part of the 1930s) precisely because he still knew then what he seemed later to forget: "contempt may not be a very formidable weapon" (L, 116). The desire to hurt—to conduct a directed assault with malice aforethought, using language as a weapon—is the defining characteristic of polemic, and also what bars the polemicist from asserting the satirist's license of social improvement or ethical instruction.

In modernity, the primary difference between obscenity and polemic is that while the latter may at times appear to be obscene in the broadest sense of that word, it is never lascivious. Polemical texts are in this way fundamentally different from those such as D. H.
